div.p: The tragedy of Albovine, King of the Lombard's: by Wm D'avenant.
London, printed for R. m. and are to be sold in saint Dunstanes Church-yard. 1629.

div.head: To the right honourable the Earl of Somerset, etc.
div.p: Ye read this tragedy, and smiled upon't, that it might live: and therein, your mercy was divine; for it exceeded justice. My numbers I not show unto the public eye, with an ambition to be quickly known; (For so I covet noise, not fame) but that the world may learn, with what an early haste, I strive to manifest my service to your lordship. I have imaginations of a greater height than these, which I do also dedicate to your lordship. And I shall live in vain, unless you still continue to acknowledge ▪

div.head: Upon the tragic muse of my honoured friend, Mr. Wm D'avenant.
div.l: Our stately tragic scene (Whose high disdains
Slight humble muses) courts thy lofty strains:
And with ambitious love doth climb thy bays,
Whose ample branches her bright glory rays:
Whence (As from heaven) her spacious eye doth view
Of storied tears, and blood, the heavy crew,
How low they crawl, while she (Far more divine!)
Sides great Sejanus, and fierce Catiline:
Where, in calm virtue, she more sweet doth show
Then Jove, when he in golden drops did flow:
But if in Stygian lake her veins she steep,
Her act infernal runs so horrid deep,
As saints Medea: makes th' Herculean rage
Seem a tame patience to thy ravished stage.
Had stern Achilles breast such fury known;
His story had turned miracle, and grown
Too much for his great poet, unless fate
Had racked his spirit up to thy high rate.
Rash imitation at thy heavenly air,
Entombs faint envy in a just despair.

div.head: To his friend, Mr. Wm D'avenant.
div.l: Why should the fond ambition of a friend,
With such industrious accents strive to lend
A prologue to thy worth? Can ought of mine
Enrich thy volume? Th' hast reared thyself a shrine
Will outlive pyramids; marble pillars shall,
Ere thy great muse, receive a funeral:
Thy wit hath purchased such a patron's name
To deck thy front, as must derive to fame
these tragic raptures, and indent with eyes
To spend hot tears, t'enrich the sacrifice.

div.head: To my honoured friend, th'author, on his tragedy of the warlike Albovine.
div.l: Great Albovine, whose fate in war had cut
His passage through the neighbouring earth, and shut
Large provinces within his grasping palm,
Had sunk from honour in the patient calm
Of a long silenced fame, had not thy pen
(With soaring language) raised him up again.
He vows, by cool Elysium (From whence
He breathed the valiant oath) he would dispense
With all those joys that court his soul, to fling
His opened breast upon the poisonous sting
Of rougher wars, if the triumphant bays
Sprung from thy ink, might crown his second praise.
This is a poet's height; conquest by thee
Described, becomes a double victory.

div.head: To my deserving friend, the author.

lg.l: Were those tragedians, whom the world so fame,
For their ingenious and admired strain,
Alive, to see this poem, and thy name;
Ashamed they'd die, finding their lines too vain.
Were that pure spring the winged hoof brought forth,
Wanting supply, dried up, thy abler pen
Would work a second wonder by it's worth,
In making it a running stream again.
Be then assured, this tragic strain shall live
A pattern for th' next age to imitate,
And to the best wits of our times shall give
Just cause of envy, for thy learned fate.

div.head: To his noble friend, th'author on his tragedy of Albovine.
div.l: The gelid North grows warm, and by thy fire
Cold ignorance exiled. The virgin choir
Of th' soft-haired muses leave the Thespian spring,
To tread a funeral measure, whilst you sing
This tragic story ▪ with sad plaints of love
Famed Orpheus charmed rude heaps, did cedars move,
Forced mountains from their station: but thy pen
Hath now amazed the fiery souls of men.

div.head: To my friend, Mr. D'avenant.
div.l: Scarce home returned, but straight I find great fame
Airing her wings to spread abroad thy name.
One of the nine (Before of me ne'er seen,
Sure sent by thee) assaults my merry spleen
With mighty verse; and makes me laugh at those
That are so dull, to melt their thoughts in prose.
I wish her prosperous flight, may she return
With happier wings, if happier may be worn.
My flame is spent. I dare not undertake
Thy praise, who am but newly for thy sake
A fierce poet, and doubtless had been one
Ne'er but for thee, or else had been unknown.

div.head: To his much-honoured friend, the author.
div.l: Let not loud envy's sulphurous blasts cast forth
Venomed aspersions, on thy noble worth:
'Gainst saucy critics thou needest no defence,
Whose sacred lines, armed with sweet eloquence,
Are proof against their censures, who'd profane.
With their bold breath, the glory of thy strain:
Wise came shall sing the praise of thy deserts,
And voice thee glorious both in arms and arts.
whilst thou, released from the war's sad mishaps,
Rests in soft dalliance on the muse's laps;
Those beauteous ladies' love shall high advance
Thy fame, whose worth exceeds my utterance.
Their tragic falls, who in thy scenes appear,
Shall on these monuments fair trophies rear
Unto their fame. Thus are thy works become
To be to them, as their Elysium.

div.head: To his worthy friend, Mr. Wm. D'avenant.
div.l: Hast thou unmasked thy muse? And shall the air
Breathe on her matchless fabric? then repair.
To some soft censure, lest the churlish sense
Of ignorance accrues thy recompense;
And hoodwinked error do surprise the fame
Due to thy story, and Verona's name,
Whose limits Pliny's and Catullus bred,
But in thy muse her joys are centupled:
For her invention, truth, rare wit, and state;
Copper-laced Christians cannot personate.
Her tragic scenes, like well-tuned chimes ith' sky,
Leave time loud echoes of thy memory.

list.item: Paradine, a captive soldier, his favourite.
Hermegild, a captive statesman, the Queen's favourite.
Vollterri, a soldier, friend to both.
Rhodolinda, captain, and Queen to Albovine.
The guard, servants, and attendants, etc.

body.head: The tragedy of Albovine, King of the Lombard's.

div.head: Act the first. Scene first.
div.stage: Enter Paradine, Grimoald, Gondibert; the drums ceasing.

sp.speaker: Paradine.
sp.p: Give the word aloud?

sp.speaker: Grimo.
sp.p: Stand?

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.p: 1. Stand! 2. Stand! 3. Stand!

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Our motion has been swift: we
Outmarch time.
Verona, (Which with the morning's dim eye
We seemed to view like landscape, afar off)
Is our full object now. She must repent;
Our King is steward unto fate; the world
Receive from him their destinies.

sp.speaker: Grimo.
sp.l: Sure, the governor sleeps. My lord, is't fit
We wait upon such silkworms, creped in wool?

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Since we attained the town not by assault,
but composition free, he shall express
Humility enough to meet us at the gate.

sp.speaker: Gondib.
sp.p: Here comes Hermegild.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Haile, young soldier! My noble Paradine!
The King must hold my nature much excused,
If I do greet his safe approach with love,
Less violent than I express to thy
Rich soul. I am resolved thou art in health,
And favour with thy stars.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Ere I return your kind salute, I would
After your fair charge inquire. Say the Queen
Smiles in captivity, my Valdaura
Hurts not her health with grief; then I have heard
Enough to make me cherish life.

sp.speaker: Hermig.
sp.l: Rhodolinda doth become her title
And her birth. Since deprived of popular
Homage, she hath been Queen o'er her great self.
In this captivity never passionate
But when she hears me name the King, and then
Her passions not of anger taste, but love:
Love of her conqueror: he that in fierce
Battle (When the cannon's sulphurous breath
Clouded the day) her noble father slew:
Our royal master once; now sunk into
His soil; where like the lily withered,
He never shall renew his growth again.
My memory disturbs my tongue! Your fair
Valdaura makes the Queen her rare and just
Example, and is in patience skilful.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Know, Hermegild, no hasty minute passed
(Since their captivity) wherein I failed
To be a suitor to the King for both.
But he's in kindness prompt, and still doth speak
Like music, when he Rhodolinda names:
you hear 'tis his edict we call her Queen?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Thy vanquished country owes unto thy fame
A tall pyramid! The captived virgins
Of our nation shall in their last dirges
Sing thy praise with mirth. O, I could grow old
Within thy sight. Something we now must talk
Together, and heaven will listen to't,
As to the breath of saints —

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: I knew we should have use of conference:
Which made me beg the leading of the van,
The more t'assist our opportune meeting.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: Afford your ears in private.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Though Paradine look flourishing, and like
A thing new brushed; a flame of triumph,
(As if his father surfeited in some
O'ergrown city when he got him) yet he
Hath in him seeds of war, bold thoughts, and we
I'th camp, esteem him honest too.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: He is our King's minion, sleeps in his bosom.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: True, and the royal fool greets him with such
Ravenous kisses, that you would think, he meant
To eat his lips.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.l: The captive captivates the conqueror.
Three moons have not expired their usual change,
Since he was prisoner to the King; though now
His favourite.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Thou'rt too loud! If thou'lt talk safely, go get
A sore throat; hoarse men speak low.
The captived Rhodolinda, (Whose father
Albovine deprived of life and kingdom)
Hath with such amorous subtlety behaved
Her gesture, that Albovine is now her
prisoner. This martial progress was but made
To visit her. She makes him guilty of
Idolatry, and knows the thrifty use
Of time: as she ascends, her countrymen
Must rise.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: You have called that Hermegild her creature?

sp.speaker: Grimo.
sp.l: He was her father's councillor; a man
Created in the dark: he walks invisibly;
He dwells in labyrinths; he loves silence:
But when he talks, his language carries more
Promiscuous sense, then ancient oracles.
So various in his shapes, that oft he is
Disguised from his own knowledge. An error
Much incident to humane politics,
Who strive to know others more than themselves.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: Observe their compliment.

sp.speaker: Grimo.
sp.l: Pox of these French jigs? Courtiers always dance.
This is to Hermegild mere lechery:
This wanton gesture doth obscure
Thoughts of such consequence and weight, as hang
Like plummets on his heart. Paradine is
A soft, easy fool, and must be gulled.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: O my sweet lord —

sp.speaker: Grimo.
sp.p: Now the motion speaks.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Such endearments would too much impoverish
My gratitude: yet, 'tis meet our actions
Carry smooth equality: your consent
Must further all my suits you are the King's
Jewel, and hang richly in his ear.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: You are precious unto her, whom loud noise
Already calls our Queen: fair Rhodolinda!
We may (If they prove natural and kind)
Govern the nation that hath conquered us;
gain our country liberty, and yet
Not stray from noble arts: such hopes our free
Embraces prophecy. The King.

div.stage: Enter Albovine, Frollo, Conrade, Vollterri, etc.

sp.speaker: Frollo.
sp.l: Your troops (Sir) are so divided into
Mixed files, that to the city you do march
Between thick walls of men.

sp.speaker: Albou.
sp.l: Let my horse-guard bring up the rear. We'll sport
With war. We have no use of safety now,
But of magnificence.

sp.speaker: Vollterri.
sp.l: The order is already given. It was
Your royal will, we hasten in our march,
Therefore each squadron double their paces.

sp.speaker: Albou.
sp.l: My boy, I bring thee home my chief trophy:
Thou dost delight me more than victory.
Retire. I am in love too violent.
My embraces crush thee, thou art but yet
Of tender growth —

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: My countryman would kiss your royal hands,
And then expect no greater happiness
Till he arrive in heaven. He hath done your
Rhodolinda service —Presents Hermeg. on his knee to the King.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Rhodolinda is your humblest captive.
She inserts you often in her prayers,
And called it my chief duty to present
Her true service to your majesty.

sp.speaker: Albou.
sp.l: Her name doth enrich our language. My boy
Can witness that I love her: she makes me
Prattle in my sleep: I've drunk mandragora,
To become drowsy, in hope that I might
Dream of her. Rise, and expect honour.

sp.speaker: Governor.
sp.l: High and sacred majesty! Verona
Hath unhinged her wide gates: proud to admit
The fate of kingdoms. Our crooked matrons
Forget their age: and (As the ragged earth
At the springs warm approach) look fresh, and young,
To entertain you. Our timorous virgins
(With the bold youth) join in one wanton choir
To sing your welcome.

sp.speaker: Grimo.
sp.p: How the spaniel fawns, 'cause he dares not bark?

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Th'amorous vine clips not the shady poplar
With such regard (About whose mossy waste
She hangs a smiling lover.) Our city is
By the reflection of your blessed approach
Like Pelion decked, whom Tython's mistress
(Leaving the weeping East) with brightness guilds.
There's not a wrinkle left in all Verona,
Wherein pale sorrow, or rebellious envy
Can find their loathed mansion. Flattering joy
Swells big each loyal bosom. All implore
You as their safety; who hath hushed the noise
Of discord, and loud war.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: The rascal flatters, as if he had served
His prenticeship in court.

sp.speaker: Albou.
sp.l: Thou'st done me justice, governor, and knowest
The way to make me thankful, but not proud.
I understand thou hast with honoured safety
Preserved those jewels to thy charge committed,
(My Rhodolinda, and my boys Valdaura.)
And so increased new motives of our thanks.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Heaven has made your memory too humble,
Thus to record your creatures service.

sp.speaker: Albou.
sp.l: Let now the knotty laborer rust with ease,
And aloud proclaim, that the upland boor
Release his teem, and his industrious plough.
Let him sing glad io's to the rustic
Powers that guard his fields, and unto me.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: It is by you we are: no warlike ram,
Nor battering engine forced a bloody entrance
Through our thick walls. It was the powerful breath
Of your victorious fame, that conquered us.
To that we yielded: which as a rough blast
That posts from the cold Arctic pole, hath born
Before it captived nations.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: By heaven a good old man! if he be learned,
I'll have him write my annals.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: Indeed he looks like a chronicler.

sp.speaker: Albou.
sp.l: Paradine? Inform him of my deeds.
Thou hast beheld my discipline full of
Shape and order, when confusion did oppress
The foe, and stifled them in throngs. Ha! Look!
Rhodolinda's come to guild our triumph!

div.stage: Enter Rhodolinda, Valdaura, Thesina, and attendants in mourning.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: And my Valdaura too! let nature show
A third object so delightful, we'll swear
She is not old, nor her first materials
Wasted, but in creation still retains
Her former strength and skill.

sp.speaker: Albou
sp.l: But why (My beauteous captive) art thou still
In sables wrapped?

sp.speaker: Rhodo.
sp.l: Your stars bid you be happy. My cross fate
Like the raven, croaks a funeral note:
this swarthy habit, but paints forth the grief
That chains my soul in darkness. And filial love
Commands me mourn for him, whom you too soon
Deprived of life, my conquered father.

sp.speaker: Albou.
sp.l: Let his ashes rest
At quiet in their urn. His ghost long since
Hath washed away the memory of his fate
In slow-paced Lethe. Take me, modest fair,
Into thy bosom. O hide me there!
My glad soul, how full is thy content?
Now thou feared thing, that guidest the heavenly empire,
Rend all the murmuring clouds, and dart
Thy thunder at me: I am safe.

sp.speaker: Rhodo.
sp.l: My captivity must needs seem easy,
Whilst the conqueror proves so kind.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: I could gaze thus on thee, till my wonder
Did convert me into marble; and yet
My soul would in herself retain a fire,
Lively as that which bold Prometheus stole.
Were the sea coagulate, and the world
Returned to th' antic chaos, a blind lump;
Thy look would force the warring elements
Into a sacred order; and beget
A harmony like this they now enjoy.

sp.speaker: Rhodo.
sp.p: You are too powerful in you speech.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Yet when I value thus thy excellence,
Let me not forget my own high being.
I've humbled all the nations of the earth;
Brought home as spoils the whole wealth of nature:
Yet, Rhodolinda, naught like thee. Let me
Whisper my content, for soft music most
Delights the female ear. They walk aside.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Why, my dear Valdaura, dost thou suspect
my warm embraces? Let hungry death cease
On my honour, before it cease on me,
If in my breast I entertain a thought
Unlawful.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: I esteem you (Sir) a friend to virtue,
And in that hope would cherish all your love.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: In thy fair brow, there's such a legend writ
Of timorous chastity, that it doth blind
Th'adulterous eye. Not the mountain ice,
(Congealed to crystal) is so frosty chaste
As thy victorious soul, which conquers man,
And man's proud tyrant-passion. But I am
Too rough for courtship, the soft harmony
Which wanton peace instructs the tongue to make,
I have forgotten. Trust me (Bright maid!)
I love thee dear. Though I've found thy heart
Like pebble, smooth, but stony.

sp.speaker: Valda.
sp.l: I've heard my mother say: the curled youth
Of Italy, were prompt in wanton stealths,
And sinful arts. Till time had given me
Assurance of your noble thoughts; 'twas safe
To doubt your love. But now I wish I were
More worthy, and then would prove more liberal
Of myself.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Let me enjoy thy hand! that moist adamant
That so attracts my soul! We will (Ere night
Her black curtain draws) make complete this love,
With marriage rites.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: How now, boy! Is my interest so decayed
In your young person, that you give away yourself
Without my leave!

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Humbly on my knee, I beg the vulgar
Privilege due to all hearts. To love, and not enjoy,
is a torture, I cannot suffer long,
And still remain possessed with breath.

sp.speaker: Albou.
sp.l: Thou hast showed me physic for my passion.
Take him, Valdaura, and be proud! 'tis I
That love him: nor shall your joys be single.
I'll make the number yet more full. This day
We'll consecrate to Hymen's use. Behold
Your Queen (Who though my captive) for her birth
And beauty, is the first of Queens.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: High heaven increase your joys!

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: And may you live together until time
Shall sicken with his age.

sp.speaker: Frollo.
sp.p: Conrad. Long live Albovine, King of the Lombard's!

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: Cry up Rhodolinda too!

sp.speaker: Frollo.
sp.p: Conrad. Live Rhodolinda, Queen of the Lombard's!

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Governor! 'tis our will that you expect
Honour, and true safety. Your city's love
I shall perceive by popular noise, and your
Behaviour in this great solemnity.
Let the sun smile; the wind sport with our plumes!
This day let sickmen too forget to groan.
Let all glad hymns in one mixed concord sound,
And make the echoing heaven your mirth rebound.

div.stage: Exeunt all, but Grimold, Vollterri, Gondibert.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: The King's head must now convert to rotten wood.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: Why, grimold?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: That court earwigs may live there, and devour
His brains. Dost not perceive how they begin
To creep into his ears?

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.l: Generous souls are still most subject to
credulity.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: He is a german in his drink: busied
With a wanton pride, which his flatterers
Admire for mirth, but his friends do pity.

sp.speaker: Vollt.
sp.p: He should be told his sins.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: By whom? Vollterri, now the King forsakes
The camp, he must maintain luxurious mouths,
Such as can utter perfumed breath, and these
Straight compose a faction, engross his ears.
They limit still his conversation.
Even as the slow finger of the dial
Doth in its motion circular remove
To distant figures: so by a subtle
Leisure, they do prefix the hours,
When he must change his rotten parasite,
For one more skilful, how t'admire, and praise.
No honest tongue can ever interpose
To tell him he is mortal.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.l: It is the chief misery of princes,
Ne'er to understand their own crimes, to sin
In ignorance.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: True, his confessor, that in sight extern
A patriarch seems, will gain by flattery,
And superscribe unto the King, as to the Pope
(His holiness.) But Gondibert,
Whom conclaves here in court do canonize
For saints, will scarce be admitted in heaven
For angels.

sp.speaker: Vollter.
sp.l: Now Rhodolinda is become his rival
In high sovereignty, she will permit
No errors but her own: the King must mend
What she mislikes.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: She gives us leisure to expect
her character. Women make themselves more known
When they do rule, then when th' obey.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.l: Valdaura is enriched with a sweetness
So religious, that Paradine must sin
In private, or need no mercy.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Thou'st named her! Though my obdurate sufferance
In active war hath quite deprived me of
All amorous gesture. Though not these forty
Winters, I have seen any of her sex
But sutler's wives, who, in stead of fillets,
Wrap their sooty hair in horses' girts. Though
My marrow is frozen in my bones,
Yet I melt before her eyes. When I see her,
I grow proud below the navel. For she
Is none of th' French nursery, that practice
The sublime frisk. None of your jigging girls,
That perch paraquitoes on their fists,
And ride toth' court like Venus' falconers.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.l: Grimold, hoarse men speak low, thou hast not caught
A cold yet.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: She's none of those that on their heads advance
High, swaggering plumes, like a gay fore-horse
In a country teem. O, she's worth the tempting!

sp.speaker: Vollter.
sp.l: Dost thou so commend her virtues, and yet
Wouldst thou tempt her unto vice?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: That's a trick I learned of the devil. Those
That are virtuous, need his temptation,
The wicked have power enough to damn themselves.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.l: Hark how they shout! Away grimold ▪ or we
Shall lose the triumph!

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Room for cuckolds, whose horns are so high ▪
They bore the moon, as she frisks in the sky ▪

div.head: Act the second. Scene first.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: This peace makes me rotten, dusty
As a cobweb. I live like a cricket
Ith' corner of an oven. Pox of these o'ergrown
Cities. To be valiant here, is to forfeit
The statute: and these furred gowns hold,
There is no sin so great as poverty.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: Thou art as melancholy as a lean judge!

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Ay, or a corrupted officer, at the noise
Of a parliament. In this division
Of unvalued trophies, territories
Vast and ample, (Gained partly by my sweat)
Not a single acre falls to my share.

div.stage: Enter Cunymond, Frollo, Conrade, servants with a banquet.

sp.speaker: Cuny.
sp.l: Bear back there! They thrust as if they meant
To get me with child —

sp.speaker: Frollo.
sp.l: You sirrah! d'ye get the King's officer
With child?

sp.speaker: Conr.
sp.l: Bear back there! or we'll put ye to the charge
Of surgery —

sp.speaker: Cuni.
sp.p: Dispatch ▪ fellows!

sp.speaker: Gondib.
sp.p: Is not that Cunymond?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: The same. He is a great astrologer.
The mere anatomy i'th front o'th calendar.
You may know where the sign is, by some toy
in's habit, which he removes, as the sign
Removes.

sp.speaker: Cuny.
sp.p: Frollo, did they enter here by your permission?

sp.speaker: Frollo.
sp.p: Not by mine, sir.

sp.speaker: Cuny.
sp.p: Nor yours, Conrad?

sp.speaker: Conrad.
sp.p: They are men of China for ought I know.

sp.speaker: Cuny.
sp.l: Then they must out. Gentlemen, pray avoid
The presence.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: Is death sir! d'ye make us your voiders?

sp.speaker: Vollter.
sp.l: Must we carry away your cheeseparingss?
Thrust your bodkins forth!

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: Draw i'th presence? Art thou mad?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: How he stands? he is created of starch,
And dares not use a boisterous motion,
Lest he should fall in rumples.

sp.speaker: Cuny.
sp.l: Sir, you may speak like a cannon! but you
Shall either go, or —

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: Or what, sir?

sp.speaker: Cuny.
sp.p: Or stay, sir.

sp.speaker: Conrad.
sp.l: By heaven he shall do one, sir —

sp.speaker: Frollo.
sp.l: Nay, captain, do not look, as if y'had drunk
Vinegar. You must, or go, or — stay sir —

sp.speaker: Cuny.
sp.l: Hey! we are tumbling in a drum.
Within.fellows of the guard, make way there! Officers!
Open the door —

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Bear back there! Gentlemen! what d'ye mean?
Pray bear back —

div.stage: Enter Albovine, Rhodolinda, Paradine, Valdaura, Hermegild, Thesina, etc.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Phoebus will be thought more rash than Phaeton,
If now he hasten to the West. Sir, this
glorious day, merits well a longer age,
Then what is limited to all within
Our calendar.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.p: Hermegild, thy free heart adds to our triumph!

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Sir, I've some few words, I needs must utter:
Since my last services in Hungary,
You remain on my tally six thousand
Ducats: I'm loath to score up still, and pay
Myself with my own chalk.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.p: Wouldst have thy soul dismissed a natural way?

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: I would not starve, look, like a parched anatomy
Sowed in a kidskin. Pay your debts, sir!

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: I never met with boldness, until now!
My courage is quite puzzled!

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Do your ears blister to hear this? My breath is
Wholesome. I cannot tipple like a duck
In a green pool. Nor feed on berries in
A hedge, like some lost remnant of my fathers
Scattered lust. Sir, pay your debts!

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.p: Sure, thou art some spirit! I cannot kill thee!

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: In this division of the lands, I helped
To conquer; I am not furnished with
A molehill for a pillow.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Hermegild sat chief in the committee
For division of those lands: bid him reward
Your service: besides, I mistake the custom,
Or 'tis my treasurer's office to pay
My debts, not mine.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: No sir, (Thanks to your royal thrift) it is
Your office to pay all; your treasurer's
Custom to pay nothing. Thrusts him away.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.p: Do not interrupt my marriage rites!

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: I cannot take your reference for payment.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.p: Would thou wert dead!

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Sir, I'll make my ghost, my executor,
And walk after death, ere I'll lose my money.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Sit, my Rhodolinda: this is thy sphere!
In th'absence of the sun, we must receive
Our light from thee. Paradine, thy bride expects
Thy service.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Sh'as an ill bargain on't, to rule one night,
And ever after to obey.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Captain, though the King be prompt in mercy,
Yet hath he so much anger in him,
As will express him mortal. 'tis for your
Safety, to avoid the presence.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: I'll bribe your lordship with a ginny toothpick!

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: You must repent this language.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: He must not, Hermegild!

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: How, my lord!

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: These whom you number in your faction,
Enjoy, by your assistance, proud structures;
And fertile granges, to maintain their gaudy
Riot. Sir, you had a frail memory,
Or a degenerate heart, when you forgotten
His merit; might you incorporate those in one,
The sordid bulk could ne'er make up his shadow.

sp.speaker: Hermeg.
sp.p: I am prescribed my discipline in court!

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Grimold, away! 'tis my desire you leave
The presence.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: I am obedient (Sir) to your desire.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: 'Slight, thou hast made a brave retreat.

sp.speaker: Vollt.
sp.l: I looked when both of us should taste
Of immortality.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: He that inflamed this fire, will scorch his busy
Fingers. My lord, it was unkindly done
t'affront my anger thus: but I have hope
It is your last fault.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: I cannot reckon it among my faults.
Sir, you involve your meaning in your speech.
The world shall find me honest.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: You are a bridegroom now.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Hermegild, make your anger known,
For else your frowns will cause your loyalty
To be suspected. This night should be as smooth
And pleasant, as that to which we owe our blessed
Nativity.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Sir, you are great on earth! I am merely
Your creation. My passions do afford
Your high delight all sympathy.
Old time hath thrown his feathers from his heels,
And slowly limps in's motion to prolong
This triumph: but if Paradine affront
Hymen, and me with sullen rage, it shall
Be called my piety to suffer.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: How! your excellence ought t'excuse my speech!
When your victorious sword deprived me of
My father; I entered to captivity,
As to th'oblique shade, where death inhabits.
Till you allowed me Hermegild; who with
His high philosophy did make
My bondage sweet. My father loved him well:
He was his noblest servant, and must not
For his virtues suffer, until your sacred tongue
Forbid me share with you in sovereignty.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Boy, this was a bold crime. You must not give
Me cause to chide my fond heart. Valdaura,
Urge him to proffer friendship
Unto Hermegild; you are powerful
o'er his nature. I have deserved to lose
My chief prerogative —

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: I am too timorous to deal with anger:
If he prove stern of nature, my marriage
Is my funeral. My lord!

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Paradine, I've an humble love. I will
Present it first to your refusal —

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: I want your phrase, to make my manners seem
Less rugged. All that is love, I cherish
With such religious heat, as my Valdaura
Claims, since our young nuptial —

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: This embracement is a sacrifice
To thee my Queen: whose deity
Consists of love. Sit, and with your
Persons, straight entrench the table. Some wine!
Fill in my German plate; I'll drink as when
I'm hot with victory. This to my bride —

sp.speaker: Cuny.
sp.p: Sound high!

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: More wine, and noise! Now boy, I celebrate
Valdaura's health —

sp.speaker: Cuny.
sp.l: Bid their instruments speak louder.
They're afraid to wake the neighbours.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: This is legitimate blood of the rich
Corsic grape: precious as thy tears
(My royal girl) when thou art penitent
To heaven. Whilst the King talks, they drink.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Spare me in the next, and I'll esteem you
Courteous; so much wine will put me to the charge
Of physic.

sp.speaker: Cuny.
sp.p: Your lordship owns it as a prime virtue —

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Shall the world bleed? but frown, and thou renew'st
A chaos. Malign the pride of some far
Eastern Queen, whom travellers bely,
and I will forage there, like loud thunder!
Or like the Northern wind upon the main,
Where lazy hulks are tossed like chips.

sp.speaker: Rhodo.
sp.p: I merit no such compliment.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: I'll do't. 'tis thought, I am immortal.
The chief of my great ancestors, that made
A wild incursion o'er this fertile soil,
Was but a type of me. More wine! — thy breath
Is as the smoke of spices. I taste thy
Melting lips, and straight engender kisses.
Heart! Boy, you are too ravenous!

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: I ever held your majesty my best
Example. Kisses nimbly gathered,
The faster grow.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: The Lombard's use to share this sport! He kisses Thesina.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.p: Is not your name Pigwiggin?

sp.speaker: Cuny.
sp.l: Pigwiggin! your grace was wont to call me
Cunymond: I am no fairy.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Nor I the King of fairies. 'slight, sir, d'ye
Present me with a cup, made, o'th bottom
Of an acorn, or Queen Mabb's thimble?
Fill me a bowl, where I may swim,
And bathe my head, then rise like Phoebus from
The ocean, shaking my dewy locks.
A health to Caesar's memory. Boy, do me
Justice, or thou affront'st my triumph!

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: Conrad, the King will drown us all!

sp.speaker: Conr.
sp.p: You've now, sir, but the moiety of his draught.

sp.speaker: Rhodo.
sp.l: Though fame lends you her trumpet, gives you leave
To speak your own praise, you cannot utter more
Than my belief shall warrant.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Now thou whisperest like the amorous lute!
I am the broom of heaven, when th'world grows foul,
I'll sweep the nations into'th sea, like dust.
Thy father was magnanimous, and great
King of the Girpides. Yet his title
Sat not so nobly on him, as my conquest.
Know, his unkind fate, was his chief glory:
For it was I that slew him; and thou his
Captived daughter art my Queen.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Sir, if you continue this narration,
I shall weep.

sp.speaker: Albou.
sp.l: Do, weep! then on my heartstrings I will thread
Thy tears in stead of pearl: such a wealthy
Bracelet, love would present unto his Queen:
And she tuck up her sleeves, to show her gawdy wrists.
More wine! Bring us the bowl of victory.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Sir, you engaged your royal word, never
To present that fatal object.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Paradine, do not resist my pleasure.
I'll crush thee into air.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: I am in my ambition virtuous,
If I desire t'expire a sacrifice
To loyalty. Sir, ruin what you made,
But do not violate your vow.

sp.speaker: Albou.
sp.l: Hence! I shall delight in fury!
sp.stage: Enter Cunymond with a skull, made into a drinking-bowl.
sp.l: Welcome, the horrid trophy of my chief war!
Rhodolinda, I'll try thy fortitude.
This was thy father's skull: thou shalt pledge a health
Unto his ghost. He drinks ▪ all rise up.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: O fatal! my eyes shrink within my brow!
I gather agues like the spring, and tremble
Like the unlicked lamb, newly yeaned upon
A sheet of snow.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: Hide me, Paradine! the object doth so
Penetrate, that when I wink, I spy it
Through my lids.

sp.speaker: Albou.
sp.l: Tame, feeble soul! Will she not pledge
What we do celebrate? Return her person —

sp.speaker: Cunym.
sp.l: Madam, the King —Strikes him, and exit.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: The king's a tyrant, and thou his slave.

sp.speaker: Frollo.
sp.p: That's a favour, signior.

sp.speaker: Cunym.
sp.p: I wear it as a jewel in my ear.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Fly, dear Valdaura; sweeten her censure
Of this act, and mediate for the King.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: Thesina, prithee help me in discourse;
My wonder (Wench) doth so disturb my speech,
I fear I shall grow dumb.

sp.speaker: Thesi.
sp.p: The work is pious we attempt.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: The harmony of your sweet tongue is his
Best physic: divorce him from those black thoughts,
Whilst I employ my utmost skill, to win
The Queen to his embraces. She's great of soul,
And may determine what my fond heart laments
To prophecy.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: You're my best countryman, kind and loyal.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: So pale and timorous! I'll sooner couple
With a mandrake, and beget groans.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: My royal lord!

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Ha! Am I alone? Have they all left me?
Where is my empire? Do I govern in
The vacant air?

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Sir, am I lost unto your memory?
You were wont to trust my service: the way
Unto your couch lies here —

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: None shall be proud but I. My smiles revive
The dead: but when I frown, the living straight
Melt into ghosts.

sp.speaker: Cunym.
sp.p: Lights for the King there!

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Cunymond, you are too officious! The King's
Departure must be private.

sp.speaker: Frollo.
sp.l: The King is light enough himself: he needs
No torches.

sp.speaker: Cunym.
sp.l: And heavy enough! for he seems to reel
With his own weight.

sp.speaker: Conrad.
sp.l: No masks! No epithalamion now!
Call for a bonesetter, for time hath sprained
His feet, and goes awry.

sp.speaker: Rhodo.
sp.l: O Hermegild! A general eclipse
In nature, would not seem so horrid!
To cut those cordial strings which Hymen had
But newly tied.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Ay, there's the horror! whilst his vows sat warm
Upon his lips; his breath not mingled yet
With cooler air; thus to perturb by stern
Practice your sweet rest, was worse than perjury.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: To present my royal father's skull,
In drunken triumph.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Take heed! you will distract your memory.
There's a record, time strives to lose; and fame
To hide beneath some oblique fold in her
Thick volume, as loath to discredit all
mankind. Your father valued you next to
His interest in heaven. I've seen the good
Old King search for his picture in your eyes; than —

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: No more: patience is sinful now. Thou art
Deeply read and wise: instruct me to be bold,
For Albovine hath taught me to be cruel.

sp.speaker: Hermeg.
sp.l: You're now by holy church incorporate;
Therefore divinity forbids me use
My natural motions. How ere I think
It fit, you give him direful cause, soon to
Repent: repentance sure is physic for his soul.
Paradine and is young bride! Your excellence
Shall please that we retire: whilst I disguise
My kind gesture, and seem to flatter in
The King's behalf —

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: To bed soft modesty! I will myself
Deliver to the Queen the King's intent.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: Sir, the King is cruel. Should you prove so
To me, I'd soon distil my soul to tears,
And weep an ocean deep enough to drown
My sorrows, and myself.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: 'Twere stern guilt to doubt my nature. Fair saint,
To bed, I long to lose my youth in warm
Embraces, and ere the pearly morn appear,
Make thee a teeming mother. To bed! with winged haste
Expect my presence.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: How smooth appears the brow of youth!

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Haile Rhodolinda! the royal mistress
Of this night. Thus Albovine (Our great King) bade
Me say, you're dearer to his eyes then light.
Though every bride may claim from Hymen
Privilege to rule her lord, till Hesperus
Appear, and cancel her brief charter.
Yet he doth humbly beg, you'll not infringe
The Lombard's custom, whose virgins never vow
A continence the nuptial night.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: I yet want your meaning.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: 'Tis his chief hope that you will straight expect
His person in your bed.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: How! lie with him? I'll sooner choose a mansion
In a sepulchre: there commit incest
With the raw remnant of my father's bones:
Sooner embrace an airy incubus:
Mingle limbs with some ulcerous cripple,
Able to infect an hospital.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: O take heed! Take heed, fair majesty! let not
His rash sin provoke you to intend so dire
An abstinence: ere yet the wine hath lost
Th'unruly operation. The King disclaims
His wanton pride, and mortifies himself
With sullen grief.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Canst thou suspect, I will prove inconstant,
To what in cold temperance I determine?

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: Heaven avert you should approve your error.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: I'll kneel, and vow with all solemnity —

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: O hold! 'twere black impiety in us
To suffer such a horrid crime. You may
Inform the King of my religious loyalty,
Already I have used persuasive speech
To reconcile this odds: but she grows wild,
Repugnant to all mercy.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: As you esteem your royal self, or us,
Who (When kinder planets ruled) were servants
to th'unhappy King your father; cherish
No more this anger in your breast, lest time
Afford it growth and violence, till it
Disturb the world.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: He counsels like a sacred oracle.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: I will inform the King, your continence
You only celebrate to this black night,
And give him hope, that you'll hereafter smile,
His kind enticements meet with equal heat,
And fertile love. Though I'm unhewn, and shaped
In war, this softens all my faculties —

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Stay, Paradine; didst thou not name my father?

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: I did with a devout remembrance!

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: And thou knowest how thy good country suffers?

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: I think on it, and my heart hangs heavy
On its strings; galls them with its sullen weight.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Hermegild oft receives certificate
From some in bondage there, which written in prose, do,
I'th reading into verse dissolve: so sad
The business is, so fit for elegy.

sp.speaker: Hermeg.
sp.l: So sad a requiem yet was never sung,
Though the hoarse raven, and the whistler shrill,
The owlet, and the evening dorr made up
The fatal choir. The young men there are yoked
In pairs, and stretch their sinews in a teem,
To draw the wealthy harvest to the grange,
Where th'insulting foe resides. The aged
(Heretofore in purple clothed) that disposed
Of law and justice; are now sowed up
In dunghill clouts; and dwell on parched hills,
To tend the flocks; whose fleece the victor wears
In gawdy triumph.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: O harsh captivity! Our country groans!
Till now I thought the conqueror 'gan to ease
Their bondage, not add to the weight of their
Compelled burdens.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: The king's a stern tyrant.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Yet he hath used me still with gentle power,
Taken me from the cold earth, and warmed me in
His bosom: and Hermegild has full cause
To bless his bounty. But you (Now our Queen)
He values next to heaven; howe'er this rash
Error strives to disgrace his love. We are
His captives too; heretofore not heeded
By our stars; though we now grow tall with titles
And his favour.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: My lord, the King is kind! Our memories
Were frail, should we forget what hath so much
Pertained unto our knowledge. I'm so fond
O'er my religion, I dare not taste
Ingratitude: yet give me leave to say,
You may mistake his love unto the Queen.
The dry tartar, who yokes his females neck
With rusty iron, not with carcanets
Of threaded pearl; whom he preserves for physic
More than increase; will the first night of their
Conjunction, feast her in's embroidered tent;
Call her sovereign; and like some amorous wind,
Sport with her hair.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: But my nuptial the King did celebrate
In Golgotha, where skulls, and dusty bones
Inhabit.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: You're skilful in the deeds that appertain
To strength and fury; but they that aim
At victory in court, must practise smooth
And subtle arts. Wise favourites do walk
i'th dark, and use false lights. Nay, oft disguise
Their breadth and stature; seem lesser than they are:
For know, the slender worm, or nimble Grig,
May wriggle down into th' oblique, and low
Descent o'th narrow hole; whilst th'overgrow snake
Peeps at the brim, but never can view the bottom.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Think on thy country, Paradine! Is there
In story no mention of some great soul,
That did his country prize above his own
Mortality, and died to gain his nation freedom?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: The noble Brutus for his countries' health,
Made Cesar bleed; Cassius was heroic too,
And had in war loud fame, which he increased
By mingling in this act. — 'tis wrought with skill,
And apt leisure. His thoughts grow numerous,
And engender horrid shapes; such as fright
His fancy.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Paradine, good night!

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Hymen and your bride, will blame your tardy
Service. Sweet lord, a thousand times good night.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: False unto me! when thunder wakes the dead:
When the sky looks swarthy: the clouds like ink
In water poured: when the earth seems to stand
As in a gloomy shade. When the wind blows
Till it grows hoarse: till it convert
And sprinkle seas even to a dew; then I
Shall try the King, and fathom his wide soul.
If he start, complain of his mortality,
Kneel oft; and pray aloud, as heaven
Were deaf: if thus, I will conclude him false.
For horrid storms that tyrant's waking keep,
Do rock the noble conscience safe asleep. Exit.

div.head: Act the third. Scene first.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: I knew your excellence did visit me
For mirth and laughter.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: So early up? Your lord is temperate.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: I should like their tempers better, if she
Were down, and her lord up.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.p: Fie, Thesina, your tongue's unruly.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: The morning might have shown me too for mirth,
Had not the false King made the night so sad.
Black fancy fly!

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: She moves as she were sick, this skirmish has
Much weakened her.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Dost thou call't a skirmish?

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: Ay, madam, a French skirmish; where th' onset
Is hot and fiery, but the retreat cold and tame.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: Madam, the King?

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: He greets your excellence in a smooth phrase,
And begs, you will permit his early visit.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: I'd rather lose my eyes then see him.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: When you did triumph in your father's court,
My entreaty then had power to alter
Your commands; reward my young service
With kindness to yourself. When the tall
Cedar falls, with burly weight it strikes
the neighbouring shrubs, low, into the ground:
So we that spring like rushes near your root,
Must in your death receive a funeral.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: What's this? D'ye moralize?

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: The King may have his anger warranted.
For heaven forbids such wild division ▪
Between those whom holy church unites.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Hark, Thesina! She has been gossipping ▪
With the holy sisters: she preaches to me
Of matrimonial zeal. Troth Valdaura,
If thy husband do infuse such schism,
I'll practise a divorce.

sp.speaker: Thesina.
sp.l: We court ladies grow so squeamish after
We have tasted man. Your majesty may
Much profit her behaviour, if you
A while divide her from her lord.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: So soon? Ere time permits them second
Their embraces?

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: I hermegild. If those embraces do
Include such high delight, such rhapsody;
She makes me envious then ▪ since all my hopes
Are widowed by the King. Tonight , Valdaura ▪
You are to sleep beneath my roof. This I
Impose as a command.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: Is not this a harsh compulsion?

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: Sir, I willingly obey it. But as
You're noble, use your ablest skill, t'instruct ▪
The Queen how of her anger to dispose
A safer way, than 'gainst the King.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Alas! I'd rather cut my eyelids off
To prevent sleep then lose one minute that
Could advantage a design so pious.
And be it part of your kind charity,
to endear me to your lord. 'tis all the pride
In my ambition to do him service.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: Sir, he already knows your worth, and thinks
Your friendship precious. Exit.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: I kiss your fair hands. The King already come?
I must seem pensive as the night.

div.stage: Enter Albovine, Paradine, Cunymond, Frollo, Conrade.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: She's lost, my boy: blown from my fist: her wings
Have gathered wind: they fly (Like those of time)
Swiftly forward, but never back return.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Sir, I have hope, she will repent this breach
Of duty, and court your royal smiles again.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Is it a sin to drink? Nature has given
To fishes a prerogative, greater
Than we enjoy. They can ever tipple
And not be drunk.

sp.speaker: Cuny.
sp.l: Fishes are dumb (Sir) they never fox themselves
With talk.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Slave! thy mirth is treacherous! Paradine!
Thou hast consumed tonight the wealth of love,
Wasted thy lips in moist kisses, embraced
A warmth, that would give life to marble.
Whilst I, (Like the solitary phoenix)
Expect no heat but in my funeral flame:
And strive t'engender of myself. Yet boy,
Thou canst not make me envious; thou art more
Delightful; then my Rodolinda's sins.
Let me survey those blue circles: his lids
Fall down, as if weighty plummets hung on
their sins. Thou art not temperate. Preserve
Thy dear eyes. Love was pictured blind, because
It makes men blind. I hug thee as my health —

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: He bruised me in his arms. Can love express
Such violence, and yet be false? Hermegild
Still whispers in my ear, the King doth hate
Thee, Paradine. But Hermegild is read in all
The arts of court, and strives perhaps
My sense to poison with lean jealousy.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Sweet lord! Y' appear blushing like the morn!
Something your bride and you have done to increase
The number of the worthies.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: He courts me too! I want a perspective,
To draw these distant figures near my sight.
I never shall sleep again.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Hermegild, thy aspect shows ominous!
How thrives our embassy?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: I have consumed my breath, till I grew faint,
And wept to invite her mercy; but tears
Were spilt like water in the forge, only
To enrage the fire. She doth abjure your visit.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.p: Harsh, iron, nature!

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: The King seems fettered in his limbs: he wreathes
His arms, as if he meant to bruise his heart.
And Paradine doth find my charms predominant.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.p: He that drinks, forfeits his mortality!

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: How sir, must we not drink?

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Soldier, to keep thy bladder moist, I will
Permit thee gape i'th morning's face, and catch
Her mizzling tears.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: If you'll extirpate this vice of drinking,
Give order for a privy search i'th the ocean;
There dwell the greatest drinkers. The whale (Sir)
drinks deeper let's hale her on shore, and impound her
In a cistern.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Good! we will embark for sea. I press thee up
For this employment.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Stay (Sir) ere I engage myself in new
Services, pay me for my old. You rest
Upon my ticket, six thousand ducats;
And I have not seen your majesty's face
In any other metal, but your own
Flesh and blood these three months.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.p: Thou grumblest like a grey wolf.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: 'Tis then for hunger, sir.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Captain, you mistake the King. He's royal
As his blood, and liberal as the sun
That shines on all. This unruly breath, where
The city meet in council, might perhaps ▪
Blow their purse-strings loose, so fill the exchequer.
And than you shall number your pay with your own
Fingers.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: I will outroar thunder, or the cannon!
Must they still walk in wealthy furs; whilst men
Of merit here are clothed in cabbage leaves?

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: Grimold, you endanger your friends.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: My lord, give losers leave to speak. I've lost
My youth and blood ith' wars, and I want food,
A reverend ass bears my wife and her young eggs
In paniers up and down the streets. I travail
Like a tartar, with all my family
About me. Nay, nay, nay! you would be gone!

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.p: Art thou not yet dead?

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: You must not move, till you've paid me. I know,
You may be angry with more safety than I.
Bid some colossus of your guard cleave me
with his falchon; yet I shall steal a passage
O'er the black river, when Charon slumbers,
And fright your grace.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: I dare not strike thee (Old man) lest thou shouldst fall
To dust, and choke me.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Good King, pay me. I love thy grace:
And will fight for thee, whilst I've motion left
To stir a feather. My want constrains me to't.
By this hand, I'm fain to eat bran and parsley
Like a tame rabbit.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: Lend me your ear, captain!

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: You'll entice me now t'enter into bond?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: You look indeed like a young heir. Well, sir,
Value me according to my true rate.
I am your friend. You make ill choice of hours
For help of your design. The King hath now
Sad and tumultuous thoughts about his heart.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Great men are always sad, when they should pay
Their debts.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Sir, you interpret ill. Grow more sober,
Then challenge all my power in your behalf.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: He that receives a kindness from the devil,
Shall be sure to lose by his gains.

sp.speaker: Cuny.
sp.l: Captain, you should choose a luckier minute:
The King is now in love.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: With whom?

sp.speaker: Frollo.
sp.p: With the Queen.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: In love with his own wife! that's held incest
In court: variety is more luscious.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Be powerful in thy speech, my Paradine,
Yet gentle too. She is the star that rules
My faculties.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: The Queen will bless your temperance, and repent.
Hermegild is too busy: he must be more
At leisure, and I more active.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.p: Hermegild, wear thy senses near us —

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Your majesty has a frail memory
To forget me so soon —

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: You'll forfeit me, and the King's mercy! away!

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: 'Tis no piece of unkindness to wish thee
In hell, for all thy friends dwell there. Thou'st none
Upon the earth. Gentlemen will you be open to me?

sp.speaker: Cuny.
sp.p: In all parts, sir, but our purses.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Draw near! let us communicate our hearts!
Does not that wealth, which you disburse for powders,
Perfumes, clothes, and physic for the face,
Return with gain?

sp.speaker: Frollo.
sp.p: Expound your riddle, sir.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Have you not each a mistress that maintains
You in expense and riot? Ha? Fame gives
It out, you smooth gallants are much obliged
Unto the sins of ladies.

sp.speaker: Cuny.
sp.l: Conrad can prattle somewhat, sir, to that
Purpose.

sp.speaker: Conr.
sp.l: Good faith you do me wrong. I've worn, sir,
A lady's slipper in my hat, or so.
Frollo is the man that gets their pendants,
Armlets, rings, and all the toys of value.

sp.speaker: Frollo.
sp.l: Excuse me, sir, not I. Signior Cunymond
Has all the voice at court. We know, sir, when,
And where, a certain Duchess, sir;
You copulate with titles, you.
The heralds are your bawds.

sp.speaker: Cuny.
sp.p: Hold! grow particular in such a theme as this!

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: Well, gentlemen, I must be furnished too.

sp.speaker: Cuny.
sp.p: With a mistress?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Yes, inquire me out some old land-carack.
I am content to stretch my loins for a
Pension.

sp.speaker: Cuny.
sp.p: At what rate do you value yourself?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: I was never pawned, sir.

sp.speaker: Cuny.
sp.p: How, captain!

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: In this lean age, we value all things
According to the rate, they pawn for.

sp.speaker: Frollo.
sp.l: But we must know, how much you would receive
In price of your activity?

sp.speaker: Conrad.
sp.p: You must never stray after fresh pasture.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Some eight; ay, ay, eight hundred crowns a year will do't.
I am desirous of no more than will
Maintain my Jennet, and my dwarf.

sp.speaker: Cuny.
sp.l: Your excuse procured, 'tis fit you now tell,
How far in your defence I may engage
My honour: is not your flesh a little tainted!
Are you not unwholesome?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: O death, no; no, no, no! do not think I have
A conscience so ill bred, to put myself
Upon a lady, when unfit for the affair.

sp.speaker: Cuny.
sp.l: Well, captain, now with your own eyes survey
Your limbs; what use can a lady have
Of you? To propagate the cough o'th lungs?

sp.speaker: Frollo.
sp.p: Or beget cripples, to people an hospital?

sp.speaker: Conrad.
sp.l: Or produce another nation that may
Wage fierce battle 'gainst the cranes?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Yet I can follow your bodies with rough
Motion, and not shed my limbs by the way —

sp.speaker: Cuny.
sp.p: I told ye, he'd make a jest on't.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: But I will kick ye in earnest, — kick ye
for my exercise and warmth — till my toes
Grow crooked —

div.stage: Enter Valdaura, reading to herself, then Albovine, Hermegild.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: Pursue Valdaura, sir.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.p: I hate these jiggeries.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: You know, I am material in my speech,
Full of duty; you want the silken garb,
That must endear you to the lady's eyes.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.p: Yet I am loving in my drink.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Greet her kindly, sir: 'tis Paradine's bride.
You have not seen her since she endeavoured
To increase the number of your subjects,
With loss of her virginity.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Rhodolinda doth so engross my love,
That on other ladies I've but little
To bestow.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Sir, practise but your courtship here. In troth
You must affect the amorous cringe, gestures
Smooth and pliant; it will never do else.
I've heard the Queen complain, you are too rough:
And what these ladies do observe, will take
A sudden flight unto her ear. Strike but
Their senses gently with your tongue. Often
Flatter 'em, and with a vigorous breath;
They'll then implore the Queen in your behalf:
And, sir, th' endeavour of their praise will soon
Procure your peace.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: If they would soften Rhodolinda's heart,
And reconcile me to her smiles, I would
Grow fond, and dally then with all the sex.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Begin your trial. If you salute this,
(And other ladies too) with some impression on
Their lips; with managing their fingers thus, —
With seizure on her wrist; as if you had
Some business with her pulse: than you inchant.
Be flexive in your smiles, and wanton like,
Seek pictures in their eyes: and when they move,
Then with personal conduct, guide their feet.
'Mongst them you cannot seem too cheap. They will
Admire you for't, and sing your praises to
The Queen.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.p: I shall be taught to spin, and starch!

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: The engine's now compact; each wheel doth move
With silent screws. The mole's the subtle pioneer:
For when she undermines the earth, her slow
Motion makes no noise. Exit.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: You're devout, Vauldaura. Teach me to pray:
We have no leisure for't in war; and 't has
Been long time out of fashion here in court.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: I fear I make some breach of duty with
Your excellence, to hinder thus
The passage of your royal thoughts.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: You teach me now, t'excuse my own abrupt
Demeanour; but I can do't. My harsh Queen
(Whom the perspicuous eye of heaven forgive)
Doth much mistake the posture of my limbs,
And gesture of my tongue among your sex.
I never use, like rugged Polypheme,
To dandle cubs. Thus, I can gently touch
A lady's lips — yet make no battery on
Her teeth. Was it not an airy pressure?
Tell my proud Queen, I've lost my iron garb,
And now am grown thus fond and smooth.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: O royal sir, her cruelty hath put
My eyes unto th'expense of many tears.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Ay, but in vain! Those clouds must weep apace,
That mean to penetrate the marble, or
The flint. I wear no gauntlet on my hand,
Why should you think that I would bruise
Your fingers with my touch —Sports with her hand.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Is this Paradine's garden?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: I madam, and your excellence may find
A sudden growth, in all that shadows us.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Ha I look there!

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: What is 't your eyes so eagerly discern?

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: The King! How sportful he is grown? how full
Of amorous game and dalliance?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: I spy Valdaura there: but is that the King?

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Thou dost inquire, t'affront my sight.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: You must inform the Queen of this: say, I
Am smooth, and musical, and trim, and that
I talk no more of war, nor drink.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: 'Tis my duty to urge all circumstance,
That may credit you in her esteem.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: It is a piece of courtship to salute
At parting —Kisses her. exit Valdaura.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Is that a safe conjunction in so hot a climate!

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Hell and death! What raw discipline is this?
I should conduct her in her way —Exit.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: So violent in pursuit of your game?
Let's follow, Hermegild?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Not for all the sun beholds in's journey
Through the world —

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Why? be nimble in thy speech!

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: It shows but silly art in industry,
To seek what you would not find.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: I pray thee grow particular! Dost think
They purpose ought ith' dark? or, was this same
But ceremonious form! such a greeting
As courtship will admit in public interview?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: The King was never given to compliment,
You know. As for Valdaura —

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: What of her?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: I think that she is chaste, but —

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Do not involve thy language thus
In periods of suspense.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: I wish the King had not deserved to be
Deprived of your soft embraces, than
He might have kept his constitution tame.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: O, is it so?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: It ill becomes the garb of majesty,
To run thus neighing (Like a riotous horse)
After each female that he spies.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Why, does he use it?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Madam, you question me, as if what I
Declare, were to your knowledge new and strange.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: By heaven and so it is.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: O my officious soul! must it be my crime
To give the information up? would I
Had known the King was here, you should have made
Another path, your walk.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Hermegild, you did misspend that breath.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Alas, you had enough of grief before.
This addition will but show a tyranny
In fate and me. It works with height, like new
Mighty wine! as if 't would split the cask.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: O perjured, black, adulterous King! affront
My father's ghost? Disturb his ashes in
His tomb? When drunk with pride, he mocked me with
The gawdy title of a Queen, and now
I am become a stale for all his lust.
Valdaura too! so pure of heart (Forsooth)
That she would blush to see her own hand, if naked:
They are proscribed. Know, Hermegild,
Our country shall be free.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: This is a noble rage! Heaven knows how I
Have grieved at your decay of soul. 't was my
Sad fear, that all the angry sparks, which were
By justice kindled in your breast, had been
Extinguished quite, now they grow up in flames.
You now like Phoebus show, when he hath washed
His face with dew. Your influence doth infuse
A noble heat, such as would motion give
Unto aged statues; make them pluck up
Their mossy feet, and walk.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Thou givest my sense's pride! What in this great
Business wilt thou do, to encourage hope?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: I will mingle poison in my ink, write
With a raven's quill! 't will be a fatal
Scripture: and shall charm like to those wise jigs
The Syrens sing. Some must direction bear
To our pensioners, that in our country rule
The stern edicts of law: some to martial
Spirits, who with their able skill do lead
Those regiments, the King hath garrisoned
I'th bordering towns. They shall revolt, my Queen,
And seat thee in thy father's chair: they must
Be drunk with the elixir of my gold.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: When first I chose thee out for this great work,
I saw thee thorough a perspective reversed;
For thou didst seem much lesser than thou art.
Kneel, and be happy! — before
The genius of this place, and what is here
Immortal, I vow to assist with my
Most active skill, all thy designments 'gainst
The King; and when my just hopes are finished,
To be thy wife. Such as do perjured prove,
Lightning will surely clothe with subtle flames,
And they shall burn like glimmering tapers
In dark hell: pale, and sickly as that fire
The ghost of Nero makes.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: This new ambition hath so exalted
All my faculties, that I seem taller
Kneeling, then when I stood. But here with strict
Solemnity I vow to teach my soul
New ways of merit: to revenge with stern,
And horrid wrath, the Kings proud tyranny.
To make your greatness absolute, and high,
Or sink myself lower than a plummet,
In the Baltic sea. Should I not this perform,
The stars would fall like cinders on my head:
And winds imprisoned in the earth; break forth,
In a wild ruin, and shake me into sand:
Then blow me in your eyes; where if in tears
You drown me, I am entombed in pearl: and then
My obsequies requite my death.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Enough. I profit to thy lip, the first
Taste of my affection —They kiss, then rise.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: 'T was moist and luscious! I will cherish this
Endearment. Trees that tallest grow, do take
The deepest root; so I must first sink low
Ith' earth; and after climb to fathom clouds.
First, praise her mimic laughter: when she weeps,
Then gather up with covetous regard
Her tears for scattered pearl. Lick her spittle
From the ground: this disguised humility
Is both the swift, and safest way to pride —

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Sure, Hermegild, I have amazed thy sense,
Thou lookest like some o'ergrown fiend, chained up
Within a silent cave. Let us retire, and I'll
Discover how I've practised my revenge.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: I project to make you mighty! You shall
Ascend my beauteous sovereign, till you
Can reach the moon, and pick those seeds of light
(The lesser stars) from forth their wand'ring spheres;
To wear as new embroidery on your sleeve.
I long to hear your fatal arts. Let's mix
Our senses, and contrive. A woman's will,
Is not so strong in anger, as her skill.

div.stage: Enter Paradine, a gentleman and page.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: You bring no letters from Cracovia, sir?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: None, my lord.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: Nor from Sienna?

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: Your lordship in those few, receives th'entire
Purpose of my journey.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Alas, my countrymen! Captivity
Is hoarse, they have more griefs than tongue: they speak
Not loud enough to wake the ear of heaven.
Henceforth to Hermegild bid them direct
Their sighs; for I'm so dull, so weary, and
Neglectful of ambitious ends, that I
Shall lose my strength, and favour with the King.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: My noble lord, our prayers will overrule that prophecy.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: You may expect, whilst I am able to
perform. Boy, bespeak the gentleman a free
And bounteous welcome. Sir, I will hasten
Your dispatch.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.p: My lord; I have tired myself in your search.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: The fair Thesina? You are rarely here
A visitant! Where have you left my bride?

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: With the Queen, my lord, who is so fond
Of her attendance, she'll scarce allow her space
To wink in her own service, and tonight
She lies within her chamber.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Ha! so soon divided! Th'approaching night
Should help to second our embraces.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: You're now to trust my art. For Valdaura
Sent me t'express her joy, i'th delivery
Of this message. You shall lie with her tonight .

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: How can my faith admit of this, since she
Is billeted where the Queen sleeps?

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: I'll perfect my assurance; so you'll please
T'obey what I enjoin. When you approach
The sphere, where your bright Phoebe rules, do not
Occasion so much noise, as shall express
You living. You must not speak to her, nor
By your gestures, invite her speech. All this
Perform, lest you should wake the Queen.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: To be dumb in copulation! This is
A fine receipt to get a silent girl.
But I shall prove obedient.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: And (Sir) as you're merciful to ladies
(Ripe in growth) do not breathe too loud, lest we
Ith' neighbouring room, o'erhear the harmony,
And sin in wishes.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: Fear not, Thesina: I shall be temperate.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: But you young soldiers are so boisterous,
you'll think anon, you're battering some town-wall.
Follow, sir, I'll direct ye to the place,
Where, when the dark hour arrives, you must
Address your visit.

div.head: Act the fourth. Scene first.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: The early lark climbs higher than his voice;
And whispers into Phoebus' ear, a glad
Welcome; who smiles, and seems to prophecy
A gawdy day. Valdaura? Madam? speak,
Sweet lady! or, if for concealment of
Our stolen rapture you silence still assume;
Yet rise, and bless my eyesight with thy fair
Presence. Come, and eclipse the envious day!
Not talk ith' business, nor yet behold
The ground we till, as if we both were blind
And dumb. I'll no more by stealth engender;
Cripples are got thus. Kind Valdaura, speak!
sp.stage: A hand is thrust out between the arras.
sp.l: See, a new day breaks in her hand! These are
The rosy fingers of the morn!
Ha! the Queen! Valdaura! Bride, where art thou?

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: In vain thou callest. The cannon's iron throat,
Although high mounted on you 'Pinnacle,
Scarce could reach her ear. She's in Pavia now,
Two leagues situate from hence.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: Thou art mysterious as an oracle!

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: I sent her thither, with pretence she should
survey the model of a garden-work.
But 'twas done, that Thesina might entice
With apter leisure, thy person to my bed.
At noon thy wife returns.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: I've mistaken than my warm embraces,
And sinned with thee th' adulterous Queen!

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Thou hast enjoyed what Albovine with all
His royal sighs, his tears swollen bigger than
His eyes, despaired to merit.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: O horror! gape, rugged earth! Suck me in
Like some old pyramid, whose ponderous limbs
Have been thy burden since the flood, and now
Their own foundation sink. Could you make
No choice to quench your ravenous lust, but me?
Where were the broad-chinned Zwitzers of your guard?

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: This (Paradine) denotes a melting brain:
Which out of vulgar pity I forgive.
'Twas not the wanton taste of thy smooth limbs,
That could provoke me use this stratagem.
But love of my revenge. I've strongly now
Engaged thy power, to kill the King.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Which do: and ere the sun arrive ith' West;
Or with dishevelled hair, my vestments torn
(As if I'd wandered thorough some hawthorn hedge)
I will approach the tyrant, acquaint him
With this deed, and call my own adultery
Thy foul rape.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Who is within there, hoa! My hogshead's empty.
I was not born with so much brains, as would
Bedew a clout, that my cold nostril stopped.
These court smocks contain the very devil.
Good heaven! how lean should I have made my heart
with studious thoughts, ere I the skill had reached
Of such a damned projection.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Collect thy scattered thoughts. What thy respect
To thy captived country, could never charm thee
To revenge; be prompted to, by a kind
Affection of thy own dear life: revenge
Upon a tyrant; one, that loves not me,
Nor thee; unless in speech: he hath a smooth
Tongue, but a rugged heart. My Hermegild
Perceives this truth, and can deliver it
With all the pride of knowledge.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Sure time grows humorous with age: for things
Do differ much from the sincereness of
Their first creation. I will go weep
Till I am blind —

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Stay, Paradine. If thou dost mock my hopes
With a slow motion in this just design,
Expect to find my anger fatal. I'll to
The King, and make a forfeiture of both
Our lives: but if with hardy sinews thou dost march
To is throat, and slit the swarthy pipe, I'll call
Thee then my soldier. Besides thy country's thanks,
Thou shalt enjoy me for thy Queen, thy wife,
Paradine.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: New arts, t'involve imagination!
How can this be, and my own wife strongly
Possessed of health and nature!

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Wouldst thou embrace so eminent a bliss,
Without some danger to thy soul?

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: My memory betrays my skill! I know
There are a thousand ways to discard her,
From this foul, dirty orb.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Alas, good easy soul! She'll never be missed
among the living. Know, Valdaura's false.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: How! False!

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: She is a open whore, and hath taught me
This art of lust.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: More horrible than hell!
Now furnish but my hands with an hourglass,
And a long dart, than seat me on some rotten
Monument for the picture of lean death.
Make me the common executioner
Of nature. For ere long I shall become
The sexton's pensioner to fill his graves.
Valdaura false!

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Wilt thou thus leave me in a wild suspense,
Whether I shall find thy courage active?

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: For credit of your own humanity,
Do not infringe the vulgar privilege
Due to all hearts. Give me but leave to think;
And never doubt your business! Though I'm a young
Sinner; yet I shall soon inquire the way
To hell. 'tis a continued thoroughfare
From this climate thither. Or let me but
Delay my journey, till the trivial rage
Of Christian princes, meet in horrid battle;
And than I shall have company enough:
Whole throngs to choke the throat of hell.
Good night, madam.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Ere yet the morn is fair cheek hath lost her tears,
Dost call it night?

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: To me it seems the eye of heaven doth wink.
All things are clothed in darkness, black as your
Design.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Stay, for else my rage will not permit
That we survive another meeting.
If thou suspectest we are too loud, I will
Distil my thoughts into thy ear.

div.stage: She hangs about his neck whispering.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Though t'assist my great hopes with opportune
Induction, I consented to this act:
Yet now I chide my fond spirits. For who
Dares trust th' unruly appetite of youth?
What I decreed she should but taste, she may
Delight to surfeit on. It shows fulsome!
Here's the precious medicine that must restore
Health to my hopes. Follow, gentle lady.
You see 'em now?

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: Fall, fall, you thick and spongy clouds, until
You choke my sight. Do not my eyes begin
To bleed at this object?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Mark how close they meet: what variety
They use in lust: now she hath melted quite his lips
With her hot breath, she hangs upon his ear.
Survey their gestures still. Now they depart.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: I'll summon all the hierarchy of heaven
To censure 'em!

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Who knows but they are gone to wallow in
Their active sweats again? Alas, pure soul!
You perceive these figures no idea,
No object of the mind, or air incorporate
To cheat imaginary view.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: Was this the cause, that made th'adulterous Queen
So strictly urge my swift journey unto
Pavia?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Ay, and the motive that provoked my soft
Conscience to hasten your return, that you
Might tell sad tales to heaven. For I
(That still was nursed upon a sibyl's lap)
Who with prophetic milk did nourish me,
Can deeply guess at th'ominous portent
Of sin. I hate such loose-reined stallions;
Such lascivious harmony in guilt.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: So soon prove false? ere the celebration
Of our marriage rites were fully ended?
Ere the sun in's journey o'er this region
Had twice beheld thus incorporate
By holy church, and smiled upon the hopes
Of our increase?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Ay, there's a contemplation that would crack
Even heartstrings made of wire. Hymen's taper
But newly lighted, and he with rude breath
Blows from the quickening week the gawdy flame.
Then in the dark, thus wilfully mistakes
Your bed, and riots between unlawful sheets.
Horror! horror!

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: O my sinister stars! Thus I shall weep
Till I have emptied all my veins.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: What should such white and harmless souls as we
Do crawling o'er this mountainous earth? Alas,
We cannot drink, till we intoxicate
A whale, nor surfeit, till our greasy cheeks
Do swell like th'udders of a cow. Nor can
We kneel like warm idolaters, unto
The rusty metal in a bag. We want
These helps to gain us honour and esteem.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: I have a resolute intent to die,
And seek my mansion in a purer orb.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: But ere you do begin your last walk, ith' path
Invisible, some meritorious act
(Joined to the charter of your creed) should help
T'assure your future bliss.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: O name it, ere my sorrow shall decay
Me strength: for I would mix ability
With will.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Your lord (Foul, and sinful as mortality
Can make him) salamander-like, shall bathe
In blue fires, unless by sufferance here
On earth, he penetrate the hearth of heaven,
And soften their decree. It will be called
Your merit to revenge his crime, even with his death.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: Would you have me kill him?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Since I am strict to virtue, I must needs
Be cruel unto vice. Let him not live
To increase his own guilt, and betray more
Ladies.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: But shall I justice take from powerful heaven,
And use it with such cruelty?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Believe me skill in sacred oracles,
My piety to warrant the design
Nor will I fright the frailty of your sex,
With horrid circumstance; he shall not bleed,
This viol doth contain a draught; which if
In's usual beverage poured, will cozen him
Of's leprous soul in his most quiet sleep.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: I do suspect my courage!

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Take't, fair pupil! think on't in your prayers.
If you but enjoy one single motion
That informs you it is good: do't with pride
And boldness masculine. Distinguish thus
Its operation. Four days must fully take
Their room ith' calendar, ere it effect
Our hopes. Before that hour arrive, he must
Be wrought to kill the King.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: The viol liquid lead contains, or else
Some far more ponderous metal: for whilst
I bear it thus, the weight seems to infuse
A palsy in my hand. I tremble like
A string touched on my lute.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: It is the fiend, that would dehort you from
A pious act: trust not his whispering charms
But with a hardy courage, (More than is
Natural in thy modest sex) proceed
To merit heaven. And now requite my forward zeal
To virtue, with concealment of my name,
And interest in this act. Let not the Queen
Nor your false lord, know me the perspective,
Through which you saw their ravenous lusts, but say,
The King revealed it to your ear. 'twill make
Them wild, and doubt their own confederate bawds.
Think not I forbid it as a danger
To my person; for I affect not life.
So soft and easy-metal is my heart,
So well I love your sinful lord, that when
I hear the surly bell proclaim his death,
Like some new weaned babe, I shall die crying.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: Would you have him killed, yet love him thus?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Ay, but I love heaven better. Where, when
I come, troth I shall prove too fond a saint.
Those votaries that pray to me, shall find
