Their business soon dispatched: here, let this key
Obscure ye in my Clozet until noon:
For then the Queen expects you will return
From Pavia. Farewell, the most abused,
but noblest lady in the world.

div.stage: Enter Grimold (In an old rug gown, muffled with clouts) Gondibert, Vollterri.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.l: This is the privy gallery: place the chair,
Vollterri, where it needs must interrupt
The King's passage.

sp.speaker: Vollt.
sp.l: If thy disguise should fail us, Gondibert
And I must be attached for impostors.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: And then be crop-card too, like Irish nags.
You'll both prove fleet in a race, provided
The foe charge ye in the rear. Seat me with
Tender motion — this luxurious city
Hath made me so rotten, I dare not walk
Ith' wind, lest I should be blown in pieces.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.l: Quick now counterfeit! Here comes Hermegild. Grimold groans.
Groan out like a boar.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: Who owns that sick clamour?

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.l: One (Sir) presented here to tempt compassion
From all charitable eyes.

sp.speaker: Vollt.
sp.l: Want hath betrayed him to hunger, hunger
To this disease.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: O, o, o, the cramp! the cramp!

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: Where, sir?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: In my stomach.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: That's indeed a clear symptom of famine.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: I've eaten nothing this month but raw air,
And that gives but weak nourishment to age.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: It is my wonder, in a state so rich
as ours, a climate still befriended thus
By nature (Flourishing with hopeful springs,
And summers choked with wealth) a soldier should
Be forced to make his hunger a disease.
A prodigy unparalleled, that want
Should e'er occasion such a dangerous fast.
Wast not devotion made him thus abstain
From meat?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Pure want, sir, I know small devotion, I.
For though I fast much, I pray as little
As most Christians of my calling. Groans again.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: He must be sent unto some hospital,
There eat warmth broths, till he recover health:
And then I will procure him from the state
Some thrifty pension, to maintain the short
Remainder of his life in sober works.
He shall sing hymns, and pray to the kind saints
In a blue gown.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Alas, sir, I am grown so hoarse, the saints
Can hardly hear my orisons.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.l: He will prove (My lord) a chargeable cure:
For the physicians do prescribe him naught
For medicine, but aurum-palpabile.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: The elixir of gold would surely much
Assuage the grief in my stomach —Groans.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: He must needs be hungry, that like th'ostrich
Can digest metal.

sp.speaker: Vollt.
sp.l: The King for his last services remains
His debtor six thousand ducats. My lord,
You shall express much charity, if you
Procure it in a sudden payment. The same will
Defray his sickness charge, and maintain him
Well in's health.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.l: Your lordship shall engage us then to drown
Your chief title in the best grape. We'll drink
Your health, until we raise the price of wine.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Let him continue there his seat. Perhaps
They (Whom I shall straight conduct this way)
Will so commiserate his want, that he
Will soon relieve't, though he increase his own.
There is some art in this, which I must needs
Discover, or forfeit my pains. Exit.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: The fiend is gone!

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Will all the vast accruements I project
From this disguise, convert into
The slender purchase of an hospital?

sp.speaker: Vollt.
sp.p: Thou turn votary?

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.l: He'll pray in no language but the High-dutch,
The angry tongue, which seems to threaten more,
Then implore.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Six thousand ducats for a mansion in
An hospital, no bigger than a coffin:
Where like Carthusians, we must feed, not to
Prevent hunger, but to hinder lust. Princes
May easily pay their debts, when they enforce
Their creditors to buy titles and place
At their own rates.

sp.speaker: Vollt.
sp.l: Hark! there's somebody approaching hither.
'Tis no safe game to sport with Kings. I'll be gone.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.l: Grimold, now trust to your own performance,
I may have use for my ears, I would not
Yet leave them in the pillory.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Gondibert, Vollterri! forsake the storm
Ere ye are wet? Weasels! Monkeys! Dogs!

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Madam, you are now fully satisfied
Ith' intention of this visit. I wish
You'd be as free, and sportive with him, as
Your modesty will give you leave.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.p: Trust my obedience, and my skill, sir.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.p: He looks like a watchman in that rug.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Your majesty receives new cause to doubt
The truth of his disease, from my servant's
Information. Who swears, this very morn
He hath been seen in all the violence
Of drink, and ith' Burdelli too. For, sir,
Though he be old, he's given much to propagation.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Let us retire between th'arras, and we
Shall share, ith' whole discovery. He groans.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: Alas, who is't, that so provokes the tongue
Of pity!

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: An old soldier of the Kings —

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: Ha! Captain Grimold! how come you thus
Imprisoned in a chair? have you the gout?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: I am not rich enough t'enjoy the gout.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.p: What name then do you give to your disease!

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: The physicians call it famine.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: How? Heaven secure the state! I hope we are
Not guilty of a sin so horrible,
To deny a soldier fit materials
For conservation of his life.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: 'Tis fourteen days since I have had a just
Occasion but to pick my teeth.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.p: Alas the day!

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Each of my thighs are dried, and hardened like
an old Westphalia flitch. All m'entrails
Are shrunk up. My bladder is no bigger than
A pigs: and were my lean jaws unmuffled,
You should see me mump, like a matron that
Had lost her teeth.

sp.speaker: Th●s.
sp.p: O cruel stars! —

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: Ha! Does she weep?

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: Could you on this wide earth, find no object
For your fury, but brave grimold? Or is't
Because you saw, it was my chief virtue
To affect a soldier?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: If she should be in earnest now?

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.p: I hope you do not utterly despair of life?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: I may linger out a score of years, or so;
But I cannot live long.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: Since you are marked for sudden death, cold death
That silenceth all tongues: and since this place
Is so secure from neighbouring ears, I will
Disclose, what until now my modesty
Enforced me to conceal.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: I shall forget to counterfeit!

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: Know, sir, that I have loved you long; loved you
With soft and tender passion.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: O rogue! What do I like the picture
Of winter, in this withered habit? I must
Recover my health. But alas, madam,
Do not deride his destiny, that now
Is taking flight to reach that place, where your
Best star inhabits, and shall have power
To tell loud tales: if you prove thus cruel.
How could you e'er love me? I have been old,
Even since your first original growth.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: But if you will permit, I may express
a little vanity in love, I can
Inform you, sir, how much we ladies prize
Age before youth in lovers. Old men are
Discreet sinners, and offend with silence.
But young men, when the game is done, do crow
Like pregnant cocks: boast to the world their strength
In folly. Besides (Sir) an authentic
Lady says in her problems thus:
The young and slender graft is easily broke,
But who can shake, or bruise the aged oak?

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.p: A rare adage.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: The lady author sure, is o'th' moddernes.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: My joy is turned to a disease; it makes
Me speechless! I ever thought these court-tits
Were much taken with my smooth looks; but that
Their modesty still kept them from my reach.
Foolish modesty! It has hindered my
Preferment much for since I left the camp,
I have been in love with some three hundred
Of 'em, yet never durst lay claim to one.
Uh! uh! If heaven should so affect
Our mutual appetites, as to restore
My health, would you continue still to dote
Upon an old sinner?

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: O, I should grow more fond; preserve you long
Alive with zealous orisons!

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: 'Las! poor malkin! She's caught! I shall grow rich.
For I have heard, these court-ladies allow
Large pensions to their paramours. Help! help!
To move me higher in my seat —

div.stage: She takes him by the hand, he rises.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: Bless us! methinks , sir, you begin to use
Your legs with active strength.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: A precious ape!

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.p: He will show fine tricks anon!

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Some strange influence from your touch, hath given
A second youth unto my faculties:
Before, I seemed to crawl like to a crab:
Now my joints grow supple, as if I were
Provided for a race. This hand inspires my strength —

sp.speaker: Cuny.
sp.p: I have a key, will give us passage here to th'park!

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: Unhand me, sir, for I shall forfeit all
My fame else. They'll think, I am immodest —

div.stage: He spies them, then drops down in's chair.

sp.speaker: Conrad.
sp.p: Captain Grimold!

sp.speaker: Frollo.
sp.p: He sits like a witch, sailing in a sieve.

sp.speaker: Cuny.
sp.l: Ha! sick! Gentlemen, avoid the windy side,
Lest he infect ye with his breath. I know
His disease, and whence it came, shortly
You'll see him wear a curtain sore his nose;
That's now the newest fashion that came from Paris.

sp.speaker: Frollo.
sp.l: Ay, 'tis it: he has them growing on his
Temples here — they'll shortly be as big
As turnips.

sp.speaker: Conrad.
sp.l: He must to Rotterdam, to the fat doctor there,
And be stewed in a stove, until he spit
His venom out.

sp.speaker: Cuny.
sp.l: And whilst you are in physic (Captain)
You fare like Oberon. 'tis a very
Slender diet. The lean thigh of a wasp
To dinner; and some two or three of your
Own penitent tears for your beverage.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: I've but so much breath left, as would make up
a short prayer to secure my last jaunt:
Yet I will spend it in a hearty curse
For your dear sakes.

sp.speaker: Cuny.
sp.l: March on! If he do find himself aggrieved,
Let him send me a challenge after his death;
And I will meet him, ith' Elysian fields.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: I will eat that Cunymond!

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.p: How prompt the slave is, in is metamorphosis?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: To him again, madam?

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: Alas, dear captain, what bodily hope
Can a young lady have of your performance,
That fall so soon in a relapse?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: When you deprived me of your hand, you took
Away my strength and heat: touch me again,
And I shall walk stiff as Cacus. She lifts him up.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.p: Take leisure in your motion, sir.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Look, madam. I creep as other mortal do,
On the surface of the earth —

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.p: methinks you stand upright too.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Ay, a lady's warm hand will make it stand.
A little physic from your lip, and then
My cure is quite finished — hem! Sure this was
Nestor's receipt to recover his youth. Hem! —

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.p: I shall be fainted for this miracle.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: I am as wholesome as a nut, and have
As proud flesh about me, as the youngest
Gamester of 'em all.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.p: Fie, sir!

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: If this heat continue, I must e'en call
For a julip, or sow my wild oats
In the next soil I meet.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.p: Your tongue is blistered ▪

sp.speaker: Grimo.
sp.p: When shall we solace our bodies?

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.p: Your meaning, sir?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: I mean ith' dark. Speak, pretty finch with the
Green tail? Ha! Must we kiss close, and often?
Wriggle up and down like young eels —

div.stage: Hermegild comes behind him, and pulls him by the arm.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Captain, I have brought the King here to view,
And to commiserate your lean sickness,
And your feeble wants.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.p: Thou old ravenous goat!

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: He looks now like an alchemist, that is
Broiling o'red herrings.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: Or like the brazen head, when 'twas about
To speak —He takes the King aside.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: You mean to hang me now!

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.p: Hast thou deserved an easier sentence?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: When I am dead, than all my debts are paid.
For I leave small lands and chattels behind me.
But hark ye (My liege) you may pay your debts
In your life time, so deprive your executor
Of a trouble.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: O what a trivial exit shall I make
From my own world? for when I die, I die
For love.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: And I for lechery. Sir, I would fain
Depart in quiet like other young Chrysomes:
Fain make all even between the world and me.
I beseech your highness discharge my arrears
For my last service in Hungary,
Then hang me when you please.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Captain, I will be a suitor for your reprieve.
You shall only forfeit what his grace owes you;
And than your life's secured.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: I will rather die twice. O sir ▪ pay me
Six thousand ducats, and then proclaim
Your sentence here aloud. I would fain die
Merrily. I have not been drunk at my own charge
This four months.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Hermegild, iterate now thy sweet raptures.
Speak to her; for, by th' gentle carriage of
Her eyes, I do perceive she begins to penetrate.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: Away captain! be gone whilst you are yet
Mortal. I have much power with Hermegild,
And will upon your patient sufferance
Redeem my credit with your thoughts. Quick then,
Move with silence.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Madam, the feathered arrow sings ith' air,
Ere it arrive where it must wound; so this
Sweet harmony, I'd have you counterfeit,
But tempts him to security in sleep,
Before his death.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.p: I'm much obliged to that good soul.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: True, my royal lady! yet now peruse
The greatness of his being ▪ his fate in battles,
And by your own remembrance be informed
Of our captivity.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.p: Honest Hermegild?

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: He was too cruel to a nature so
Remiss, and timorous as mine?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Alas, this crime he expiates with sighs
So hot, that they would sing his royal beard,
Did not his numerous tears opportunely drop,
To quench the flame.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.p: That's compliment!

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: These angry frowns upon your brows make you
Appear aged.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Could I assure my heart; he would no more
Triumph o'er my dear father's memory;
I then should meet his love with too much passion.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: When I am more my chronicle, or speak
My deeds with pride, may my tongue blister, till't
Infect my breath with epidemic-heat.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: You hear his vows? — seem fond. If you can shed
A tear, or two, the more to credit this
Atonement, 'twill much advantage our pretence.
Sir, now enjoy what your indulgent grief
Merits to keep, e'en from the hands of death.
Good heart, see how she weeps?

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: I'm soon o'ercome in this soft war. 'sdeath all
Can thaw but I. I never wept, but when
Th'unruly wind blew in my eyes; and 'tis
No argument for stern battle: else I
Would fight. To testify the joy my soul
Conceives, I'll drink —

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Sir, you neglect to use her like a lover;
With amorous gestures.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Fill me a bowl with negro's blood, congealed
Even into livers! Tell her, Hermegild,
I'll swallow tar, to celebrate her health!

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Sir, this dull German phrase, makes her suspect
Your temperance. Mark how she trembles.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: I must go learn to compliment. Dost hear?
Is't fit I proffer her to mingle limbs — thou knowest —

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Sir, not tonight . That was a serious suit
She bade me make, when first she purposed this
Atonement.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: I do obey. Though I have thought would fain
Persuade me to rebellion.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: This was a subtle caution! else my hopes
Had twice been cuckolded. Let 'em revel
With their salt lips. Th' other sport is fulsome.
But Paradine disturbs my sleep: he's young,
Enriched with all the fertile strength of nature:
And needs must prove more riotous in sin,
Than I. My dark practice, and use
Of silent contemplation; has made
My marrow thin and black; like ink within
My bones. I want the prompt alacrity. The Queen
Hath tasted him, and may (Perhaps) still to
Possess his lust; remove Valdaura from
This foggy soil; then make him lord of all
My hopes. This to prevent, I have decreed,
Valdaura first shall minister his death.
I've taught her too; to insinuate to his creed,
That the King told her of is adulterous lust;
Good, for when he thinks the King doth know that guilt,
His own safety then, will soon provoke him
Hasten our prodigious murder. This may
Be done, before the poison operate
In dire effect; for that delays its power;
Till fourscore hours expire their course: which then
No antidote, nor humane skill resists.
Mount, mount my thoughts, that I may tread on Kings,
Or if I chance to fall, thus soaring high;
I melt like Icarus, in the sun's eye. Exit.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: The sun doth melt us with his scorching beams.
Go fill my usual beverage: I'll drink
Till I am cold. Exit page.
The constitution of my soul, agrees
Not with this climate. I grow weary
Of mortality. Even in my first growth
(Since my corselet was my load) I have taken
My breeding in the camp; where had I still
Remained a dull practic soldier, and never seen
A woman, nor the court, I might have had
Some hope, to gain by faith, but now I reach
At wild despair. Enter page with a bowl.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: My lady, sir, commends her love, and this
To your acceptance; she made the mixture
With her own hands.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: The Queen prescribed this hour for her return.
That she grows black with sin, perverts my sense,
I must seem not to know't. Say, I greet her health-drinks.

div.stage: Exit page. Enter Valdaura in close mourning.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Ha! why, Valdaura, dost thou appear like
A funeral night, in dark, and swarthy weeds!

sp.speaker: Valdau.
sp.l: I mourn for you, since you must hasten your
Eternal absence now from me, and all
That else are mortal.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Speak things, that are less dangerous to my sense.
This wonder will distract me.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: Ere winged time, shall with swift motion add
Another hour, to th' life of this sick day;
Thou shalt begin thy last sleep.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: A pale swan hath sung my dirge! O fatal
Music! but how comes this intelligence
To ears of flesh and blood? have you of late
Been gossipping with the grim Stygian dames,
and seen their cisers gall my vital thread?
For to my own sense I need no physic.
My faculties enjoy that pleasant strength
Which appertains to youth and temperance;
Why should I yet die?

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: How, Paradine? Art thou so full of guilt,
(Most ulcerous and deformed) yet thinkst to keep
Thy life at nature's charge, to exist till age
Makes thee a cripple: then in thy bed,
(Like some good old patriarch) thy soul dismiss
With a divine rapture? No, no; just heaven
Provides more rash and horrid deaths for such,
As in adultery bathe their silken limbs.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: I know thy guilt; the King hath told me all.
'Twas wondrous strange! Our vows but new arrived
In heaven, that did oblige our mutual faiths
In love: and thou with savage lust to break them?
Though grief hath much consumed my tears, yet I
Have some still left to express my pity.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: My adultery already known, both to
The King and her? why, these are prodigies
Indeed. How sin emboldens the aspect!
She doth accuse me for a guilt, which yet
Remains unpardoned in herself. Mine was
A dire mistake: but hers — that must be known,
And then her veins shall weep.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.p: You are poisoned, Paradine.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: With that cold draught you sent me now ith' bowl?

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: The viper's vomit, nor the blue steam,
Which fat toads do breathe in tired motion,
Bears not such a dangerous enmity
'Gainst humane nature, as that you drunk.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Stay! Methinks I feel no insurrection
In my blood, nor need an iron corselet
To contain my flesh; sure it swells not yet.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: It takes a subtle leisure to disperse
Thorough all your organs, and your arteries,
That it may straight with abler violence
Consume your strength.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: And then I shall look goggle-eyed! and stretch
Ith' cheeks, till my face show like a pompion,
Round and yellow?

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.p: Far, far more deformed.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Will't make my eyes start from my skull, or drop
Like bullets at my feet? Speak, shall I foam
At mouth like some young courser, that is hot
And angry with his bit?

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: Not the first chaos was so ugly and
Confused, as you'll appear, when this distillment works.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Yet I forgive you all, e'en from my heart:
Whilst my cogitations now are sober,
And can distinguish things with pregnant sense.
I do applaud this cruel benefit.
These subtle vanities of court have tired
My observation. I was nursed within
Some armoury, and took a proud delight
In active war; but since our drums have ceased
Their noble clamour, I find no business
Upon earth for me; 'tis fit I grow immortal.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: I did not think, his fancy, at this news,
Could prove so temperate.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: To sleep in cold earth, whilst my dead neighbour
Never at my coffin knocks, to inquire my health,
By way of visit: for all are silent
In the grave. Harsh destiny! Such as I
could ne'er expect from thee, Valdaura.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: My nature you shall find much different,
From what your knowledge heretofore discerned.
I have contrived another way to punish
Thy adulterous heat.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: You find my sufferance tame enough. Publish all!

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: To meet your sin with apt revenge, I'm grown
A foul loose whore.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Ha! contain thy speech. Express but so much
Modesty, as may secure thy life: for
My death doth not concern my rage so much,
As this foul murder of thy fame.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.p: 'Tis truth: and I confirm't with pride.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: O, o! these are the mandrake's groans (Fatal!)
For whoso hears them, straight encounters death.
Now smile (Sweet heaven) since thus I but return
Her own justice. For my adulterous act,
She takes my life, and shall I let that bold
Adulteress live? —Stabs her with is poniard.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: O, o! Hold, hold! Leave me a little breath
To use in prayer.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: I am not fraught with devil's spleen; I would
Not hurt thy soul: here solitary sit,
Whilst I send up an humble sacrifice,
That shall bespeak a pardon for thy crime,
Ere thou arrive near heaven. Puts her in a chair.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.p: Dare you trust my last utterance?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: O speak, ere thou dost catch an everlasting cold,
And shalt be heard no more.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: I am not false unto your bed: I ne'er
In act, nor guilty thought, did violate
My marriage vows.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: Art thou not a whore?

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: No vestal that preserved with quickening oil,
The sacred flame, was in her chastity
More cold, more timorous than I: nor are
You poisoned.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Ha! was not that a mixture of distilled
Venom, which I drunk?

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: 'Twas healthful, as the blood of grapes to age,
And all your faculties do still preserve
Their wonted harmony.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Sweet spirit, do not riddle thus with heaven,
Nor sport thy soul away. Why didst accuse
Thyself of stern murder, and pernicious lust;
Yet art thus clear from both?

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: 'Twas to enrage your violence, with hope
To make you soon my executioner.
For hearing you were false, I found no joy
In life: your hand hath sealed my wishes.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: New arts t'increase my wonder: I'm o'erreached,
Where I thought my nature was most skilful!
E'en in love! O stay: had not distraction
Ceased my memory; I should at first have told you
The mistake, by which the sinful Queen
And Hermegild betrayed my chaste honour.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: Named you Hermegild, guilty of that sin?
He's then a horrid hypocrite: he did
Entice me by a poisonous practice to
Contrive your death, but found my nature loyal.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: New wonders still!

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.p: I feel the frozen hand of death. Oh! o! o!

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: Valdaura! Bride! O noble girl!

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.p: Mercy! mercy!

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Already turned a ghost! There's rare music
Now in heaven, since thou art gone t'increase
the sacred choir. I may behold thee in
The purple sky, mixed there with other stars,
But never on this soil again. Be this
Thy tomb awhile. The curtains softly drawn —
Hermegild treacherous! with poison too?
That was her word. 'tis fit I seem to have drunk
The medicine up. Good! The rough young soldier
May spy at last these spirits of the court,
That walk in artificial clouds: or if
Their high conceptions soar above my reach,
Yet they have mortal hearts; such as our own
Country steel, may with feeble motion prick,
Prick till they groan: for I have now decreed,
Whom my dull sense cannot subdue, shall bleed. Exit.

div.head: Act the fifth. Scene first.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.p: Shall I belie my own silence?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Be sudden in your speech! confirm my words:
Then dispose e'en of my wealth and person.
I will consent to matrimony; make
Any use of this new interest.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.p: Sir, you'll forget my merit in this danger?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Never. — my lord, I have discovered all.
See, how aguish her guilt hath made her.
How she trembles like a frosty Russian
On a hill. Nay, lady, ne'er scatter thus
Your wild looks. Confess the truth, and you'll gain
Mercy. Valdaura (Whose soul heaven keep
From purging fires) hath told her lord; the King
Knows of his wanton stealth with our good Queen.
You were the instrument that betrayed him
To th'mistake, and whose secrecy to doubt
But yours, our reason cannot yet inform us.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: Thus kneeling, I confess with penitence,
'T was I revealed it to the King.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Tear forth her eyes, and let her then grope out
Her way to hell —

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: Stay, dear madam!

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Paradine is poisoned, who knows, but she
Doth amply share in that guilt too?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: At my humble suit, contain your fury!
We shall discover all. My noble lord,
It is a grief that will deprive my life
Of many years, to think, I'm held by your
Suspect, an agent in that practice.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: I have revealed the evidence, that doth
Persuade my creed.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: What, lady, do you know of this? — speak with
Courage, I am your safety.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: I saw the King reach to Valdaura's hand
A poisonous viol; and with religious hints,
Taught her to mix it in her husband's draught.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: Persist in my instructions! Aside.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: 'T was that night when he enjoyed her person —

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: Enjoyed her! how?

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.p: As you enjoyed the Queen.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: Heaven! will these miracles ne'er cease?

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: I shall convert to stone!

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Now retire, Thesina, till I have begged
Your free restorement to the Queen's mercy.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: My lord, you'll not forget your kind promise
Of matrimony.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: I've naught else, to trouble my remembrance.
Away, away!

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: What did remain suspense, is here confirmed:
My forehead feels as rugged now as his.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Now sir, you've heard such real circumstance,
As needs must settle your belief, and free
My heart, from your unkind dislike.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Valdaura's damned! she howls so loud, that she
Disturbs all hell! O perjured whore!

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Now Paradine! Instruct thyself with thoughts.
Is't evident he ever could affect
Thy person with sincere dotage, yet thus
Betray thy strength in thy fort? Where thy
Honour still stood sentinel?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: I have other motives to teach you doubt
His loyalty in love. Which my fond heart
Cannot conceal, though't would advantage much
My own profit. He hath of late, hung thus —
Upon my neck; until his amorous weight
Became my burden: and then lay slabbering o'er
My lips; like some rheumatic babe. This sport
My serious brain abhorred. 'twas my wonder
(Since you are called his minion) he could ere
Affect my look. I that am like coughing
Winter, old, and froward; you the darling
Of the lusty spring.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: Speak, is that bag, that should contain thy gall,
Shrunk up; hast thou nothing bitter in thee?
Thou art far, far more opportunely stored
With time and place for thy revenge, than we.
Ith' middle age of day; when the bright sun
Most powerfully doth warm the world; in thy
Secret closet he takes his usual sleep.
Go, drill his heart! and make the couch whereon
He lies, his easy monument.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: And then enjoy a Queen, with all that doth
Belong to her achievement, or her birth.
As for my services, they merit no
Reward. I know my own creation much
Unfit for court affairs. If you but wrap
Me in a shirt of hair, than seat me in
A dark and gloomy cell, where I may tumble o'er
Some deep voluminous rabbin, you make
Me safe, and happy.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Do't, Paradine! and fame no trumpet then
Shall need to speak thy praise. Thy country will
Afford thee power to sanctify the chief
O'th' days within our calendar.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: And to thy memory high statues build,
About which our noblest virgins once a year
Shall dance in circles, and sing, until they make
The marble move, like to those loose quarries;
Which o'erheard Orpheus and his harp. Or if
These cannot inspire heroic fury,
Yet argue thus; you knew his bed, but by
Mistake; which was our guilt, not yours; and for
Our country's benefit contrived. But he
Defiled your sheets in the salt pride of lust.
Horror! this would incense the temperate dove;
Turn all his moisture into gall; teach him
To wear spurs on his heels, and make him fierce
In duel, as a British cock.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Fire! fire! and warm blood! Exit.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Follow, follow him, my dear sovereign!
Add new heat unto his rage. And d'ye hear!
Since he is poisoned, 'twere most fit, some learned
physician, did endeavour to secure
His health.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: I heard him say, he is already furnished
With a powerful medicine.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Should you now forget your royal promise,
I lose all my industrious merit,
And remain a sacrifice to love.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Dost thou grow jealous?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Valdaura now is severed from her soul:
And Paradine is abler in delights
Of youth, more moist and amorous than I.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Away fool! I seal thy safety with my lip.Exit.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Thus nurses hush their froward babes asleep.
Shortly she'll present me with a coral-club,
A whistle strung with bells. These female arts
Can ne'er my dark authentic practice cheat.
Paradine must die! So I still secure
My hopes. When that sad hour arrives,
Wherein the poisonous draught must work,
No charmed medicine can resist its strength.
I hug my genius! 't was a subtle reach,
To tell him, that the King hath horned his brow:
For that will more incense his wrath, and aggravate
The Queen's revenge. The weight I bear, doth make
My motion slow: slow as the snail I tread,
Who travails with his tenement on is head. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Grimold in new clothes, Gondibert, Vollterri.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: The King has paid him all is arrears.

sp.speaker: Vollt.
sp.l: 'T was by Thesina's suit to Hermegild:
The snake has cast his skin too now.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Ay, sir, 'tis a poor snake that cannot cast,
His skin once in a summer.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: 'Slight, here's grimold! Didst not thou say he was dead?

sp.speaker: Conr.
sp.p: But I have heard since, his ghost walks.

sp.speaker: Frol.
sp.l: Look! 't has found the hidden treasure then, which
Made it walk; for the ghost hath bought itself
New clothes.

sp.speaker: Grimo.
sp.l: Nay, nay, stay, gentlemen! Let us forget
Old quarrels, then end our new acquaintance.
We are for the country now. I'll but tell ye
A few of your faults, and leave th' amendment
To your own leisures: but you all think
You're wiser than I.

sp.speaker: Cuny.
sp.p: We should abuse our judgements else.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Mark! This is a new court-thrift: when you are
Loath to maintain flatterers, you publish
Yourselves with your own praise. Lay your fingers
Here — not a word, lest I return ye a blow.
I know ye cannot speak without a compliment.

sp.speaker: Vollt.
sp.p: They use it in their prayers, they.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.l: Cunymond, in one single compliment
So much wasted his lungs, that I was fain
To call for aqua vita to recover
His breath.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: I've heard you have transported from Paris
The geometrical cringe, and the art
Of numbering the hairs upon your chins.

sp.speaker: Vollt.
sp.p: And of starching your beards.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: Yes, and of perfuming your very shadows.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: And they say, it is your custom to sleep
In pomatum masques.

sp.speaker: Vollt.
sp.p: And that you paint your pretty physiognomies.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Yes, and colour them so red, that you seem
to blush more, than the sign of the King's head
Before a country inn.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.l: Y'abuse astrology too; for you clip
Black-taffeta into stars; and for a foil
To your beauty; fix 'em in several regions
Of your face.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: Which makes it look, like the picture of doomsday;
When all the planets are darkened.

sp.speaker: Vollt.
sp.p: Nay, nay, stay awhile!

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Leave off your jigging motion, when you mix
Yourselves in a salute; your bodies seem
To dance upon your knees. You pinion up
Your elbows thus: — like pullet's trust upon
A spit. Then wreath your hams in thus; and move
With a discreet leisure, as if you meant
To number all the pebbles in the street.
And than you fleer, as if y' had washed your gums
In vinegar. This you admire for gesture
Of the newest fashion. I say, 'tis scurvy!
For he that greets a lady so, does look
Like a soap-boiler, upon a close-stool.

sp.speaker: Vollt.
sp.l: If you will take physic for your souls-health,
Retire into that part of the kingdom
Which lies farthest from France.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.l: He counsels well: for the French air hath made
Many of our gentry drunk.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: And now move hence; but with your lips sowed up,
For fear of a compliment. You two shall straight
Take horse with me, and be billeted in
My quarter. Stay, gentlemen! One word more!
This is a hot climate: when you must needs
Marry to increase your tribe, your best way
Is to go a-wooing in the city:
for certain rich widows there, love court-fools;
And use to play with their babbles.

div.stage: A canopy is drawn, the King is discovered sleeping over papers: enter Paradine with his sword drawn.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: To make him bleed, and leave his arteries
(Where the delighted spirits walk) shrunk up,
Until they curl with heat. The withered frame
Straight to convert to dust. Then th' numerous wind,
To fan it o'er the world. Speak, just heaven!
Is this fit usage for a King? Cassius
Was rash: perhaps to gain noise at's funeral;
Or in is Elysian fields; beneath a pleasant hedge
To tell some prattling ghost what he had done —
Ha! but Brutus, noble Brutus! the pride
Of arts and war: so temperate, his soul
Was more harmonious than the spheres. Instruct
(Heroic lord) thy young pupil! Why did
The mighty Cesar fall, by thy cold wrath?
All silent as the night! He sleeps: before
Him too, those papers that concern my house
Affairs; and my official rule in state.
Here he comments on my letters! here with
Thrifty documents limits my expense.
Can this indulgent care be counterfeit?
And merely carry a pretence of love? he made
My wife a black adulteress. O horror!
Yet who knows, but 'twas rather his revenge,
Than lust; a furious riot, after that
He knew I whored his Queen —
sp.stage: He blinds his own face with a scarf, sheathes his sword, and then kneels.
sp.l: Sir! My lord the King! Sir!

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Ha! Paradine! What witty emblem's this?
The more to certify thy love, dost thou
Appear blind.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: O sir, do not mock my penitence, nor seem
Thus to disguise the knowledge of that crime,
Which hath defiled my modest blood, and makes
Me now ashamed to encounter with your eyes.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.p: He is drunk! Maudlin drunk!

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Sir, I could creep alive into my tomb,
And mix society with ghosts, whilst I
Have yet warm motion left, could I but hide
My guilt from your perspicuous sight.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: By heaven drunk with cider, or with thin beer;
That looks like th' urine of a babe: I'm sure
The Corsic grape infuseth no
Such whining passion.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Those immaterial powers, that see the thoughts of men,
When growing in their hearts, can witness I
Abused your royal bed, but by a dire
Mistake.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Your black adulterous Queen betrayed
Me to her lust by wicked arts.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: This is a sober passion, but implies
Something that is horrid.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Had not heroic war taught me to affect
No rage, but noble; she and Hermegild
Had enticed me now to lengthen this your sleep,
Until the day of general accounts.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Suspect must now be rash. Make your face known!
He blushes like a bride; whom through her thin
Curtains, the peeping sun beholds in soft
skirmish with her lord. I must counterfeit,
And seem to know all. Paradine, 'twas far
From my conjecture, that a heart so much
Obliged unto my love as thine, should wrong
My honour in a sense, which but to mould
In words would teach my tongue to stammer, and
Deafen all that hear it.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Thunder and sulphurous fire snatch my cold limbs
From this dull earth. Sir, whilst my soul affords
Me reason, and can direct me unto whom
My true allegiance is a debt, kill me!
When I am mad, I shall forget all duty,
And refuse to obey your royal charter.
Thrust your good sword home, till my heart shall kiss
Your hilts. Are you so slow in justice? Think,
How by a dark mistake, I whored your Queen:
Whored your Queen! O prodigious phrase!

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Houle, meager wolves! empty tigers! let the hoarse
Thracian bull bellow, till he rent his throat;
And the hot mountain-lion roar, until
Their clamour wake the dead. The resurrection
Is too long delayed, since we want horror
To celebrate this news. Good! I have now
Decreed it. Draw thy bright weapon! —

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: For what dire use?

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: That we may meet in single battle here,
And struggle till we want our souls.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Though this high enticement charms my blood, like
The music of the drum. Yet my remembrance
Calls you King; my royal master. I would
Not join rebellion and ingratitude
To the prolix number of my sins.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: O fond, indulgent boy! I mourn at this
decay of thy humanity and sense.
Does it become my great being, and my
Glorious name in story, to offend
Without resistance? Draw: and be nimble
In thy motion —

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: I dare not so disgrace my religion,
And my love.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: 'Tis time that I were dead, for I shall else
Outlive my chief prerogative. I have
Forgotten how to command. Unsheathe thy sword!
Or this breach of duty shall teach methink ,
I ne'er enjoyed thy real love, and 'twas
Not a mistake, that ushered thee to sin between
My sheets, but a considerate lust —

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: No provocation like to this, could tempt
A danger from my arm —He draws.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Why dost thou dally thus with feeble motion?
Bear up! and use more violence!

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Some surgery from heaven! Are you hurt, sir?
You willingly opposed your breast against
My steel, and never sought to endanger me
With yours.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: 'Thou'st performed, what my wish did prophecy:
I'm pricked here, about the heart; and my veins
Grow empty.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Then glorious war, and all proud circumstance,
That gives a soldier noise, for evermore farewell —

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Hold, Paradine. 'tis my last suit, that thou survive
To minister a just revenge on those
Whom I proscribe, help my quivering limbs,
And seat me in the chair —

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Shall posterity read it in story
and believe; a prince that doth deserve to be
The first ith' list of those, that gathered noise
In war, can be thus covetous to expire
In silence dark. Fall on my fatal point,
And yet command that I survive the tragedy!

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: 'Twere in me an affectation trivial
To cherish life, now Rhodolinda's false.
For should I still preserve my soul in flesh,
I know my mercy is so fond to her;
I should forgive her all: and wert thou dead,
My hope were then deprived of future justice.
Live to revenge her falsehood. I know thy heart
So sincere and noble, that I suspect not thee
A sharer in her guilt. When thou
Didst first confess th'adulterous crime, joined with
Thy own mistake, through Hermegild's deep art,
My faith conceived the truth: for thy nature
Is much too blunt, and credulous for court.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Should I but speak each cunning circumstance —

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Contain thy breath! To hear that told, would make
My soul wander in my last journey.
Till thy relation brought it to my ear,
I never knew her false.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Still my amazement doth increase! Were you
Not told of this before!

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.p: My knowledge only learned it of thy tongue.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Stay! Nor with Valdaura, you did ne'er project
My death by poison?

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.p: Never.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Yet one reply, then make my joy exceed
My wonder. Did you never in my bed,
Commit a lustful stealth?

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.p: Angels in that, are not more free from guilt.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: What potter made this earthy skull! pardon
(Dear Valdaura) my dull suspect! Sing out
Thy hymns in heaven ▪ and never listen more
To my fond speech; for they have made me mad!

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: I cannot gripe the air. Mark how it steals
Through all my knotty fingers —

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: Ecstasy!

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Now my last, and short minute is arrived;
I do, resign my crown —

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: To whom sir?

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: To him I hate. But be thou sure, he wear
It not till near his death: for it's a happiness
To live enthroned, but 'tis not safe to die
A King.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: He doth pervert my sense.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Let the drum cease! I'll have no more battles.
He that to waste his trivial rage, doth fight
A battle, rides a hawking with the devil.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: Mad as the Northern wind!

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: He sends a thousand drinking animals
To take their flight ith' air, whilst little black
Devils (D'ye not see 'em?) They look like ravens.
Mark how they prey on those immortal fowl,
And plume 'em in their talents! I do not like
This falconry: it is too sad a game
For sinners — o, o, o! —Dies.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: There died the noblest trophy of our war!
The Lombard's now have lost their victory.
So hardy of creation, his heartstrings
Were as cordage, tough; cracked like a cable,
When the frighted bark starts from the anchor.
All that are nursed in war, shall mourn for thee.
Our ensigns now we will of cypress make ▪Knocking.
Ha! It is the wind that whispers ▪ he must
Be hid. I'm sure this noise can never wake him —
sp.stage: He puts him behind the arras, opens the door, enter Rhodolinda.
sp.l: O, are ye come?

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Thou hast a wild aspect! Is it done?

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: He has paid for his wharfage already,
And is now entering Charon's boat.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Thou'rt precious as my soul! He opens the arras.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: There's the old face.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: He looks like a pale country virgin
That longed to eat mortar. Our chief design
Is finished: but thou must add one knot more
To oblige my gratitude, and then we shall
Triumph with safety. Hermegild must die ▪
He knows too much.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: It is as if the parca spoke. If there
Be any other whom your envy, or
Your hate would have dismissed the world, make him
But known, and he is numbered with the dead.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Dear Paradine, I sure shall 〈◊〉 thee,
My appetite is grown so fierce. Let me
Begin with thy moist lip —Pulls her to kiss him in the chair.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Let's to't like monkeys, or the reeking goat.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Oh! o! o! Help! help!

div.stage: Both are bloody about their mouths.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: Cease your loud clamour, royal whore.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Thou didst eat my lips.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Thy flesh is sour, musty; more tainted than
A carrion in a phlegmatic ditch for else
Like th' anthropophagus, I had devoured thee up.
This made Valdaura bleed, and must let forth
Thy swarthy soul —Stabs her with his poniard.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Oh! o! o! —

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: For Albovine my royal master, this —
And this to pacify Valdaura's ghost —

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: O, o, o!

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: So hard and stony is thy heart, that it
Reverts the point of my bright steel.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Mercy heaven! She dies.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Since thou hast received my justice, I wish
Thee mercy too —Knocking.

sp.speaker: Hermegild
sp.l: My lord.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: 'Tis Hermegild, now I shall end my chief
Discovery. What a full sepulchre is this —Carries her in. Knocking again.
Now I must practise my disguise. Revert
The spring twice, and you may enter.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: My lord, I have lost my honour in your service,
You may choose one that shall affect you worse.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Lady, this is no time to woo: but
D'ye think I'm so profane to violate
My vow? Nimbly depart, I do conjure
Your absence with this kiss —

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: If you should prove false —

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: 'Slight, these wenches at
Fifteen, are as riotous as elephants.
Marry a court kitten! There he sits! Ha, sick!
My sweet lord, how thrives your health? D'your pulses
Still preserve their temperate music? have you
Effected yet our great business?

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: The King is dead, that sanguine instrument
did set his soul at liberty.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: The laurel, myrtle, and the bay shall still
Cold and naked stand before the winter's
Frosty breath; still strip their boughs, to make
Your head triumphant wreathes. Where is the Queen?
Methinks (My lord) your body and your mind
Seem much disturbed.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: O, o! the poison works —

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Alas, my sweet dear lord! (Precious medicine!)
He cannot possibly survive the next
Minute. Does it destroy your strength?

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: O, o! It scorches all my entrails up:
As if like Porcia I had swallowed coals.
I spit scum, such as o'er th' hot cauldron boils —

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: And are you fastened in the chair with weakness?

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: I cannot rise. A stiff convulsion in
My sinews fetters all my limbs —

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: Ha! hah! ha!

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: O heaven, will you permit him laugh?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: I know th'ingredients of thy poisonous draught.
'Twas I that gave it to thy wife. 'twas I
Did counsel her to mingle it in thy wine,
When thou wert hot, and all thy pores open
As thy mouth.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: O, o, o!

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Do, groan, till thou raise an echo in this
Square roof. Ere long thy ribs will start from thy
Loose chine, thy lank belly swell into a hill.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: O horror! horror! Is heaven asleep?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: The King ne'er knew of thy adulterous crime ▪
'Twas I told it to Valdaura, and made
Her think, thy guilt proceeded not from a
Mistake, but from thy wilful lust ▪ I've strung
thy nostril with a spinner's thread, so led
Thee through subtle labyrinths, t'involve
Thy senses; and now I triumph o'er thy fate.
This is Italian spleen.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: Had I but strength to actuate my revenge?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Good, dull soldier! why didst thou leave the camp,
Thy rusty morion there; thy battered corselet;
And thy shivered lance, to amble here at court
In slippery silks; to walk in cloudy mists
Of perfumed air? 'tis I have shaked thy brains
That heretofore were thick as curds, into
A pale, thin whey.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Draw near, and let me then but kill thee —

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Troth, thou art so feeble now, that were I killed
By thee, I scarce should think that I were dead.

div.stage: Paradine rises, and snatches Hermegild's sword from his side.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: No! that shall arrive unto the 〈◊〉. Dog! grim
As th'angry fiend, that must devour thy soul!
I am not poisoned.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: Ha! does he counterfeit?

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: See here, what abject ruins thou hast made
O'the noblest structures in the world —

div.stage: He draws the arras, and discovers Albovine, Rhodolinda, Valdaura, dead in chairs.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: The Queen there too! O trivial arts with my
Own mine I've blown myself e'en into dust!

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: I will now see, if thou canst bleed like things mortal —

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Deprived of my defence! If thou'st a soul
(Great as thy fame) restore my sword.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Thou barkest against the moon! I will requite
thy own tyrannous scorn. That destiny
Was just, that thus betrayed thee to my mirth.
There, Stygian dog —Wounds him.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: O, o! whilst I have warmth, I'll move with violence —

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Where now are all the subtle trophies of
Thy brain? Plots, dark as hell! projections grim!
Such, as threatened nature, and seemed to fright
The genius of the world. Now, now prevent
These dire salutes —

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Return my sword, then manage steeples like
To pikes; yet, I'll affront thy fury —

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Hardy as the Scythians race, I greet thy heart —

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: I stagger, and am drunk with my own blood! —

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: Take my last anger, and good night! Falls.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: O, o! thou hast stuck needles in my heart!

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Now I do swell with horror and stern rage:
I will distract the whole world. Fire! fire! fire!
Murder, treason, and incestuous rapes! Fire! fire! Exit.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: I spy
A white soul hovering in the air! one when
Corporeal, was sure some humble hermit
Here on earth. He's acquainted with the way
To heaven: should mine take flight alone, I fear
'T would stray! Hoa! you, you that ascend the spheres!
We sinners still seem hoarse to angels ears.
What, hoa! he turns not yet: who knows but he
Still lived in low valleys, built his mansion
In some aged wall? but my path ever lay
On hills, where the good patriarchs never trod.
Vain arts! Ambition in all sacred schools,
Is held the sin of heathens, and of fools. He dies.

div.stage: Enter Paradine, governor, Cunymond, Conrade, Frollo, the guard, etc.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: O dire and tragic sight! The King, the Queen
And fair Valdaura slain!

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Here's another object fit for wonder,
Though not for pity. Spurns Hermegild.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Ha! he dead too? Whence should these sorrows flow?
Lay hold on Paradine.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: All stay. I'll bore his haggard soul that strives
With saucy strength, to captivate my limbs:
Hark, the big drum recovers breath, and speaks!
March on! The scattered foe retires, and all
The glorious horse are slain. I am magnanimous,
And high! O ye unkind false stars! ye mock
Poor Paradine! A few clean tears to wash
My sins away, and I am seen no more.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: Cease on him; on forfeit of your lives!

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Their lives are forfeited to me —
sp.stage: He fights with the guard, they wound and disarm him.
sp.l: Here, here, it galled my very heart! —

sp.speaker: Governor.
sp.l: Convey him gently in, and use all help
Of surgery to stop his wounds: for from
His mouth, we must receive the knowledge of
These fatal deeds. Some give th'alarum to
The ports! You signiors, lead to th'cittadel;
Where, we'll proclaim albovines young issue
By's former wife, to be his lawful heir.
Wild fancy may project things strange and new:
But time records no tale so sad, and true.
